key_points: The total drag is the resulting factor if you add induced drag and parasite drag together
Parasite drag is caused if an airfoil is moving through the air
It is the result of form drag and skin friction drag
learning.explanation: The total drag is the resulting factor if you add induced drag and parasite drag together. Parasite drag is caused if an airfoil is moving through the air. It is the result of form drag and skin friction drag. Form drag arises from the shape of the object. The more streamlined the object, the less form drag is present. Shape and size are most important in the amount of form drag resulting. Form drag increases with increasing velocity, making it very important for high speed aircraft. Skin friction drag is caused by the friction of the fluid (in case of aircraft this fluid is the atmosphere) against the skin of the object moving through it. It is directly related to the surface area in contact with the fluid. Skin friction increases with the square of the velocity. Induced drag is caused when an object redirects the airflow. A wing produces lift by creating a pressure difference. This pressure difference is caused by the shape of the airfoil, causing the airflow on top to accelerate, creating a low pressure on top of the wing and high pressure below the wing. This pressure difference naturally wants to restore towards a uniform pressure, which creates vortices around the wingtip. These vortices are deflected downwards, this phenomenon is also called downwash. The induced drag decreases with airspeed. In the image we can see that the two vectors (induced and parasite drag) create a resulting vector, the total drag. Where the induced and parasite drag vectors collide, we have the minimum drag speed (VMD); the speed where the total drag is the lowest. This leads us to understand that during an acceleration from a total stand still, the total drag first decreases up until the minimum drag speed and then starts increasing again.

This updraft turn into a downdraft behind the wing, creating a vortex
learning.explanation: Wing tip vortices are a byproduct of lift. Meaning that the strength of the wing tip vortices increase as the aspect ratio decreases. And vice versa: the strength decreases as the aspect ratio increases. Therefore statement 2 is correct!

key_points: The centre of pressure is the point on the chord line of an aerofoil (a line through the aerofoil joining the leading edge and the trailing edge), where all the aerodynamic forces are concentrated
The centre of pressure (CP) will move during various phases of flight, but not because of mass shifting, but rather CP moves with changes in angle of attack
The location of the wing centre of pressure forward or aft of the CG influences the pitching moment
learning.explanation: The centre of pressure is the point on the chord line of an aerofoil (a line through the aerofoil joining the leading edge and the trailing edge), where all the aerodynamic forces are concentrated. The centre of pressure (CP) will move during various phases of flight, but not because of mass shifting, but rather CP moves with changes in angle of attack. The location of the wing centre of pressure forward or aft of the CG influences the pitching moment. A centre of gravity forward of the centre of pitch has a nosedown pitching moment. A centre of gravity aft of the center of pitch has a nose-up pitching moment. To compensate for the pitching moments generated by the location of the CP, a balancing force must be created by the tailplane.

key_points: SPOILERS Spoilers are flap type control surfaces, normally located on the upper surface of the wing, just in front of the trailing edge flaps
These surfaces individually hinge at their leading edges and are actuated by hydraulic power supplied by dedicated power control units
The main purpose of the surfaces is to disturb the smooth airflow over the top of the wing, thereby reducing the wings lifting capability
learning.explanation: SPOILERS Spoilers are flap type control surfaces, normally located on the upper surface of the wing, just in front of the trailing edge flaps. These surfaces individually hinge at their leading edges and are actuated by hydraulic power supplied by dedicated power control units. The main purpose of the surfaces is to disturb the smooth airflow over the top of the wing, thereby reducing the wings lifting capability. When fully extended, they considerably increase aircraft drag. Roll Spoilers operate asymmetrically in flight whenever the control wheel rotates, assisting the ailerons in providing roll control, particularly at high airspeeds. Flight Spoilers (speed brakes) operate symmetrically about the aircraft’s longitudinal axis to increase drag, when it is required to decelerate quickly or to descend rapidly. Their deflection angle is determined from the flight deck in response to movements of a speed brake lever, typically located on the centre pedestal on transport category aircraft.

content.question: A positively cambered aerofoil will generate:

options.A: zero lift at a positive angle of attack.
options.B: zero lift at zero angle of attack.
options.C: zero lift at a negative angle of attack.
options.D: lift at all angles of attack.

key_points: Camber is the asymmetry between two acting surfaces on an airfoil
For an aircraft, this is the top and the bottom of the wing
Positive camber means that a wing is thicker on the top end of the wing, than on the bottom if looked at from the chord
learning.explanation: Camber is the asymmetry between two acting surfaces on an airfoil. For an aircraft, this is the top and the bottom of the wing. Positive camber means that a wing is thicker on the top end of the wing, than on the bottom if looked at from the chord. In case of positive camber, a wing will generate lift with airspeed, as the air on top of the airfoil will get accelerated more than on the bottom, creating a low pressure on the top and high pressure at the bottom. This is “pushing” the wing up into the air as the pressure difference wants to restore itself to 0 difference. In case of negative camber, the exact opposite happens and the lift coefficient for a certain speed is lower than for a positively cambered wing. A completely symmetrical airfoil will intersect the vertical axis of the graph at the origin (0). A positively cambered airfoil will generate more lift at the same speed (and therefore has a higher CL) than a symmetrical airfoil and therefore intersects the vertical axis above the origin (and generates 0 lift at a negative angle of attack). A negatively cambered airfoil will generate less lift at the same speed (which translates into a lower CL at a certain speed) and therefore intersects the vertical axis below the origin. The camber of an airfoil can be increased with the use of flaps. The end of the wing reaches out and/or downwards, changing the side profile of the wing and moving the CP aft, resulting in a nose down pitching moment. This generates a higher value of CL at the same Angle of Attack. Therefore if flaps are being retracted, the Angle of Attack should be increased.

content.question: Increasing dynamic pressure will have the following effect on the total drag of an aeroplane:

options.A: total drag increases across the whole speed range.
options.B: at speeds above the minimum drag speed, total drag increases.
options.C: at speeds below the minimum drag speed, total drag increases.
options.D: total drag decreases across the whole speed range.

key_points: The total drag is the resulting factor if you add induced drag and parasite drag together
It acts in the direction of the relative wind
Lift is perpendicular to the relative wind
learning.explanation: The total drag is the resulting factor if you add induced drag and parasite drag together. It acts in the direction of the relative wind. Lift is perpendicular to the relative wind. Parasite drag is caused if an airfoil is moving through the air. It is the result of form drag and skin friction drag. Form drag arises from the shape of the object. The more streamlined the object, the less form drag is present. Shape and size are most important in the amount of form drag resulting. Form drag increases with increasing velocity, making it very important for high speed aircraft. Skin friction drag is caused by the friction of the fluid (in case of aircraft this fluid is the atmosphere) against the skin of the object moving through it. It is directly related to the surface area in contact with the fluid. Skin friction increases with the square of the velocity. Induced drag is caused when an object redirects the airflow. A wing produces lift by creating a pressure difference. This pressure difference is caused by the shape of the airfoil, causing the airflow on top to accelerate, creating a low pressure on top of the wing and high pressure below the wing. This pressure difference naturally wants to restore towards a uniform pressure, which creates vortices around the wingtip. These vortices are deflected downwards, this phenomenon is also called downwash. The induced drag decreases with airspeed (with a rate of 1/V²) and increases with angle of attack and increasing weight. In the image we can see that the two vectors (induced and parasite drag) create a resulting vector, the total drag. Where the induced and parasite drag vectors collide, we have the minimum drag speed (VMD); the speed where the total drag is the lowest. This leads us to understand that during an acceleration from a total stand still, the total drag first decreases up until the minimum drag speed and then starts increasing again. If we add flaps to the clean configuration, CL will increase, but so will the drag. This degrades glide performance. The rate of descent will increase and glide range will decrease.

content.question: Some wings are designed with a smaller angle of incidence towards the wing tip or a profile with a different camber towards the wing tip. The reason for this is to...

options.A: ensure that the entire wing stall occurs when the aeroplane is at a specific pitch angle, and to create an aeroplane with predictable stall characteristics.
options.B: delay the stall at the wing tip to reduce the likelihood of the aeroplane experiencing significant rolling moments when stalled.
options.C: reduce the stalling angle of attack at the wing tips to ensure the wing tips stall first so there is a more gradual loss of lift when stalling.
options.D: evenly spread the lift across the wing planform and increase its efficiency, resulting in minimum drag at the optimum angle of attack.

key_points: In some wing designs, separation tends to occur first in the region of the tip, reducing lift in those areas
If an actual wing were allowed to stall in this way, stalling would give aileron buffet and perhaps violent wing drop
To give favourable stall characteristics, a tapered wing must be modified using one or more of the following: Geometric twist (washout), a decrease in incidence from root to tip
learning.explanation: In some wing designs, separation tends to occur first in the region of the tip, reducing lift in those areas. If an actual wing were allowed to stall in this way, stalling would give aileron buffet and perhaps violent wing drop. To give favourable stall characteristics, a tapered wing must be modified using one or more of the following: Geometric twist (washout), a decrease in incidence from root to tip. This decreases the angle of attack at the tip, and the root will tend to stall first. The aerofoil section may be varied throughout the span such that sections with greater thickness and camber are located near the tip. The higher CLMAX of such sections delays stall so that the root will tend to stall first.

content.question: Which of the following causes an increase in downwash behind a wing?

options.A: Increased dynamic pressure.
options.B: Stronger wingtip vortices.
options.C: The aeroplane entering ground effect.
options.D: Decreased lift.

key_points: DOWNWASH Downwash is the effect of a wing changing the local relative airflow
It is also the term for the air being forced downwards behind a wing
The terms are very closely linked, and often refer to the exact same thing, but there are subtle differences to how we view it in different contexts as part of the syllabus
learning.explanation: DOWNWASH Downwash is the effect of a wing changing the local relative airflow. It is also the term for the air being forced downwards behind a wing. The terms are very closely linked, and often refer to the exact same thing, but there are subtle differences to how we view it in different contexts as part of the syllabus. Evaluating all possible meanings, the only correct answer is "stronger wingtip vortices". INDUCED DRAG Whenever a wing produces lift, some air tries to "cheat" the wing and travel around the wingtip, creating wingtip vortices that affect the lift of the rest of the wing. The vortices are strongest at the wing tips and become progressively weaker toward the centre-line of the aircraft. These vortices create upwash in front of the wing and downwash behind the wing, effectively changing the local relative airflow, and therefore changing the effective angle of attack of the wing. This produces inefficiencies and means the wing's lift is produced at an angle, and some of the lift turns into drag, called induced drag. The stronger the vortices, the greater the induced drag. The stronger the wingtip vortices, the greater the downwash behind the wing. As part of producing a lifting force on the aircraft, a wing must force air to go downwards, to satisfy Newton's 2nd law of motion (equal and opposite reactions). This is referred to as downwash also, and means that the air flowing away from a wing is pointing slightly downwards, but it arrived at the wing perfectly horizontal, for instance. The amount of "downwash" is directly proportional to the lift produced, and therefore: Decreased lift produces less downwash. Increased dynamic pressure means higher airspeed, but has no effect on the magnitude of lift, and therefore downwash, and will actually decrease the angle of the downwash, due to more air flowing over the wing for the same lift force. This is assuming the same lift force, which we see as much more realistic than assuming a constant angle of attack or lift coefficient, etc., for these questions. Entering ground effect reduces the effect of wingtip vortices, making the wing more efficient, due to the reduced downwash (as the air cannot flow down as much due to the ground in the way).

content.question:
Which of these statements about the strength of wing tip vortices are correct or incorrect?
1) Assuming no flow separation, the strength of wing tip vortices decreases as the angle of attack decreases.
2) The strength of wing tip vortices increases as the aspect ratio increases.

options.A: 1) is correct, 2) is incorrect.
options.B: 1) is incorrect, 2) is incorrect.
options.C: 1) is correct, 2) is correct.
options.D: 1) is incorrect, 2) is correct.

key_points: Whenever a wing produces lift, concentrated vortices form at the wing tips
The vortices are strongest at the wing tips and become progressively weaker toward the centerline of the aircraft
The vortices induce downwash to the airflow behind the wing, causing the lift vector to tilt rearward
learning.explanation: Whenever a wing produces lift, concentrated vortices form at the wing tips. The vortices are strongest at the wing tips and become progressively weaker toward the centerline of the aircraft. The vortices induce downwash to the airflow behind the wing, causing the lift vector to tilt rearward. The horizontal component of lift opposes the forward flight of the aircraft and is known as induced drag. The larger the vortex, the greater the induced downwash, and the greater the induced drag. The induced drag can be defined by: CDI= CL2 / π*AR Where, CDI – Induced Drag Coefficient CL2 – Lift Coefficient squared AR – Aspect Ratio Increasing the angle of attack increases CL. From the formula we can deduct that Induced drag is directly proportional to CL squared. So, decreasing the angle of attack decreases CL, which decreases Induced drag. Therefore, statement 1 is correct. From the formula we can deduct that Induced drag is inversely proportional to Aspect Ratio. So, as the Aspect Ration increases, the Induced Drag decreases. Therefore, statement 2 is incorrect.

content.question: As an aeroplane slows down during the approach, the wing tip vortices and downwash will vary in intensity. How does this affect the induced angle of attack? Induced angle of attack will...

options.A: decrease, especially near the wing tip.
options.B: increase, especially at the leading edge.
options.C: increase, especially near the wing tip.
options.D: decrease, especially at the leading edge.

key_points: The airflow around an aerofoil section sets up a pressure differential between the upper and lower surfaces
The lower surface of a wing is normally at a pressure above atmospheric, whilst the upper surface is at a pressure below atmospheric
Beyond the wing tips the air is nominally at atmospheric pressure
learning.explanation: The airflow around an aerofoil section sets up a pressure differential between the upper and lower surfaces. The lower surface of a wing is normally at a pressure above atmospheric, whilst the upper surface is at a pressure below atmospheric. Beyond the wing tips the air is nominally at atmospheric pressure. This causes a spanwise flow of air outward away from the fuselage on the lower surface and an inward flow toward the fuselage on the upper surface. At the trailing edge of the wing, where the two flows meet, a twisting motion is imparted to the air and a series of vortices form. These are trailing edge vortices. The effect of these vortices is to create more down wash behind the wing than up wash in front of the wing. This results in the effective air flow (EAF) being inclined to the relative air flow (RAF) by an angle called the induced angle of attack (αi). Because of this local increase in induced angle of attack, the overall lift generated by a wing will be below the value that would be generated if there were no spanwise pressure differential. It is the production of lift itself which reduces the magnitude of the lift force being generated. To replace the lift lost by the increased downwash, the aircraft must be flown at a higher angle of attack. This increases drag. This extra drag is called induced drag. The stronger the vortices, the greater the induced drag. Induced drag increases with decreasing speed (for a constant lift force). This is because, as speed decreases, the downwash caused by the tip vortices becomes more significant, the rearward inclination of the lift is bigger, and therefore induced drag is higher.

content.question: An aircraft with trailing edge flaps and leading-edge slats is flying at a speed close to the clean wing stall speed when the flaps are extended to the landing configuration. options.B: The right wing could stall when the trailing edge flaps are extended and speed increases.
options.C: The left wing could stall when the slats are extended, after the extension of the trailing edge flaps.
options.D: The left wing could stall when the trailing edge flaps are extended and speed decreases.

key_points: Slats increase the critical angle of attack of the airfoil by delaying the separation of the boundary layer
Since the slats have not extended on the left wing, unlike the right wing, the left wing is not benefitting from a greater critical angle of attack
When the trailing edge flaps are extended, critical angle of attack is decreased
learning.explanation: Slats increase the critical angle of attack of the airfoil by delaying the separation of the boundary layer. Since the slats have not extended on the left wing, unlike the right wing, the left wing is not benefitting from a greater critical angle of attack. When the trailing edge flaps are extended, critical angle of attack is decreased. Consequently, the wings are now closer to their critical AOA. A decreased speed asks for a greater angle of attack. The left wing (slats retracted) may stall when the flaps are extended.

content.question:
Given a constant load factor, which of these statements is correct about the variation of induced drag with changes of speed and mass are correct or incorrect?
1. When speed increases, induced drag decreases.
2. When mass increases, induced drag decreases.

options.A: 1 is correct, 2 is correct.
options.B: 1 is incorrect, 2 is incorrect.
options.C: 1 is incorrect, 2 is correct.
options.D: 1 is correct, 2 is incorrect.

key_points: Induced drag is created as a by product of lift
The pressure differential between the top and bottom of the wing creates a upwash around the tip of the wing that turns into a downwash behind the wing
This is known as a vortex, which creates a rearward force known as induced drag
learning.explanation: Induced drag is created as a by product of lift. The pressure differential between the top and bottom of the wing creates a upwash around the tip of the wing that turns into a downwash behind the wing. This is known as a vortex, which creates a rearward force known as induced drag. This question is asking for the effect of: Speed: The induced drag is inversely proportional to the speed. Therefore, induced drag increases as the speed decreases, and, induced drag decreases and the speed increases. This is because, to maintain lift constant, as the velocity decreases, the coefficient of lift will have to be increased. At higher coefficients of lift, the pressure differential between the top and bottom of the wing will be greater and therefore produce stronger vortices = stronger induced drag. (and vice versa) Changing mass: Induced drag is proportional to the mass. Therefore, induced drag increases with increasing aeroplane mass, and, induced drag decreases with decreasing aeroplane mass. This is because, as the aircraft get heavier, the lift that the wings will have to produce increases. To achieve that, the coefficient of lift will have to increase, meaning a higher AoA, which creates stronger vortices. (and vice versa) Summary: Higher AR = Lower induced drag Higher AoA = higher induced drag Higher weight = higher AoA = higher induced drag Higher speed = lower AoA = lower induced drag Winglets = lower induced drag.

content.question:
Which of these statements about a steady subsonic flow are correct or incorrect?
1. The static pressure does not change as the streamlines diverge.
2. The velocity decreases as the streamlines diverge.

options.A: 1 is correct, 2 is incorrect.
options.B: 1 is incorrect, 2 is correct.
options.C: 1 is incorrect, 2 is incorrect.
options.D: 1 is correct, 2 is correct.

key_points: To understand the venturi effect, we must first introduce two conditions: The conservation of mass (Continuity Equation) and the Conservation of Energy (Bernoulli’s Theorem)
Conservation of Mass (Continuity Equation) The mass of air entering the pipe, in each unit of time, equals the mass of air leaving the pipe, in the same unit of time
The mass flow through the pipe must remain constant
learning.explanation: To understand the venturi effect, we must first introduce two conditions: The conservation of mass (Continuity Equation) and the Conservation of Energy (Bernoulli’s Theorem). Conservation of Mass (Continuity Equation) The mass of air entering the pipe, in each unit of time, equals the mass of air leaving the pipe, in the same unit of time. The mass flow through the pipe must remain constant. The mass air flow 'm' is the product of the density, the area and the velocity: m = ρ * A * V Continuity equation: m1 = m2 = m3 = ρ1 * A1 * V1 = ρ2 * A2 * V2 = ρ3 * A3 * V3 = constant The continuity equation explains the relationship between velocity and cross-sectional area: The speed is inversely proportional to the cross-sectional area. Conservation of Energy (Bernoulli’s Theorem) The total energy of an airstream comes in two forms: potential energy (static pressure) and kinetic energy (dynamic pressure). The total pressure of the airstream is the sum of the static pressure and the dynamic pressure and must remain constant, according to the law of conservation of energy. Thus, an increase in one form of pressure, must result in a decrease in the other. Dynamic pressure (q) is expressed by: q = 1 / 2 * ρ * V2 Assuming the total pressure to be constant, the static pressure and the dynamic pressure vary inversely: If one increases the other decreases and vice-versa. As an airfoil (wing) moves through the air, varying changes in velocity occur on its surfaces. Air particles move around it in specific trajectories. These trajectories are called streamlines. Diverging streamlines mean a decrease in airspeed. Converging streamlines imply an increase in airspeed. In Conclusion: With an increase in section area (from station 2 to station 3), flow speed decreases, decreasing dynamic pressure (streamlines diverge). If dynamic pressure decreases, static pressure increases. Statement 1 is therefore incorrect. With an increase in section area (from station 2 to station 3), flow speed decreases, decreasing dynamic pressure (streamlines diverge). Statement 2 is therefore correct.

content.question: How would the TODR (take-off distance required) for a fixed wing aircraft vary with increasing flap settings (from retracted to full flaps)?

options.A: It would decrease.
options.B: It would increase.
options.C: It would decrease and then increase.
options.D: It would increase and then decrease.

key_points: Learning Objective 081
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 081.01.09.01.09: Explain the effects of flap-setting errors, such as mis-selection and premature/late extension or retraction of flaps, on: take-off and landing distance and speeds; climb and descent performance; stall buffet margins. Flaps increase the camber (and sometimes the area) of the wing, which increases the amount of lift that can be produced by the wing, for the same IAS (indicated airspeed). They also increase the drag of the wing, by more than they increase lift. This means that the aircraft will always fly more efficiently (better L/D ratio) without flaps, hence why they are not used in the cruise, or the climb, when possible. Flaps are primarily used for take-off and landing. For take-off, we can rotate at a lower speed, using less runway, and maintain a lower flying speed on the initial climb out. For landing, we can approach at a slower speed (with a higher approach angle if necessary, due to the extra drag), and therefore land in a shorter distance. For take-off, using flaps is a trade-off between runway length and climb requirements. Flaps are bad for climbing, as they produce more drag, but they will get us off the runway earlier. Therefore, if there is a long runway and high obstacles around, lower (or no) flaps should be used, whereas a short field take-off with few obstacles should use higher flap settings. If there is a short field with obstacles, run the performance calculations carefully for both, and use whichever is better. In terms of this question, the take-off distance will obviously reduce from no flaps (clean) to some flaps, due to the lower distance to rotation, but will begin to increase again towards full flaps, as the aircraft have so much drag that even if it does leave the ground early, it will struggle to climb to the screen height. Many aircraft would not be able to sustain a climb at all with full flaps set, and the final stage of flaps often produces little extra lift than the last stage, but produces lots more drag.

learning.explanation: INDUCED DRAG Whenever a wing produces lift, concentrated vortices form at the wing tips. Which of the following are advantages associated with the use of vortex generators?
1. Increase in maximum CL/CD.
2. Decrease in form drag.
3. Delay in the separation of the boundary layer.
4. Increase in critical angle of attack.

options.A: 3 and 4
options.B: 1, 3 and 4
options.C: 2, 3 and 4
options.D: 1 and 2

key_points: Vortex generators, are rows of small, thin aerofoil shaped blades which project vertically (about 2
5 cm) into the airstream

The principle of operation of vortex generators is that they create small vortices that cause the faster moving air above the boundary layer to be deflected from the top of the boundary layer to the slower moving air near the aerofoil surface
learning.explanation: Vortex generators, are rows of small, thin aerofoil shaped blades which project vertically (about 2.5 cm) into the airstream. The principle of operation of vortex generators is that they create small vortices that cause the faster moving air above the boundary layer to be deflected from the top of the boundary layer to the slower moving air near the aerofoil surface. This transfers momentum and re-energises the lower layer of the boundary air, delaying the separation point to further aft along the aerofoil surface. Vortex generators are also frequently used on a swept wing to delay tip stall and improve the stall characteristics. Vortex generators are usually located on the upper wing surface, particularly ahead of control surfaces, but may be used anywhere where separation is causing high drag or reduced control effectiveness. For aeroplanes travelling at high subsonic or transonic speeds, vortex generators weaken the shockwave and decrease shock drag but have no diminishing effect on wing-tip vortices. Nevertheless, the vortices produced by the vortex generators diminish shock buffet and are beneficial to the aeroplane’s overall performance

content.question: Assuming constant IAS, when an aeroplane leaves ground effect:

options.A: the induced angle of attack decreases.
options.B: the effective angle of attack decreases.
options.C: the effective angle of attack increases.
options.D: induced drag decreases.

key_points: When an airplane flies at a height equal to or less than the length of its wingspan the efficiency of its wings is considerably improved
A low wing airplane, just before touchdown, experiences a 50% reduction of its total drag
This phenomenon is ground effect
learning.explanation: When an airplane flies at a height equal to or less than the length of its wingspan the efficiency of its wings is considerably improved. A low wing airplane, just before touchdown, experiences a 50% reduction of its total drag. This phenomenon is ground effect. Ground effect occurs because the surface alters the airflow pattern around the wings. Primarily, the surface restricts the formation of the wingtip vortices. When an aircraft enters ground effect during the landing phase of flight, the sudden increase in lift and reduction in drag cause it to experience a floating tendency. The aircraft also tends to pitch nose-down due to the reduction in download on the tail plane. The magnitude of the wing tip vortices, and thus downwash, also determine the amount of induced drag produced by the wing. The closer the aircraft is to the surface, the greater the reduction in induced drag at any given angle of attack. Aircraft entering ground effect: Downwash decreases. The effective angle of attack increases. Increased lift during landing if the angle of attack remains constant. The induced angle of attack decreases. Induced drag decreases. Aircraft leaving ground effect: The effective angle of attack decreases. Decreased lift during take-off if the angle of attack remains constant. Induced drag increases. Downwash increases. The induced angle of attack increases.

content.question: The Lift Coefficient versus Angle Of Attack curve of a symmetrical aerofoil section intersects the vertical axis of the graph..

options.A: above the origin.
options.B: below the origin.
options.C: to the right of the origin.

key_points: Camber is the asymmetry between two acting surfaces on an airfoil
For an aircraft, this is the top and the bottom of the wing
Positive camber means that a wing is thicker on the top end of the wing, than on the bottom if looked at from the chord
learning.explanation: Camber is the asymmetry between two acting surfaces on an airfoil. For an aircraft, this is the top and the bottom of the wing. Positive camber means that a wing is thicker on the top end of the wing, than on the bottom if looked at from the chord. In case of positive camber, a wing will generate lift with airspeed, as the air on top of the airfoil will get accelerated more than on the bottom, creating a low pressure on the top and high pressure at the bottom. This is “pushing” the wing up into the air as the pressure difference wants to restore itself to 0 difference. In case of negative camber, the exact opposite happens and the lift coefficient for a certain speed is lower than for a positively cambered wing. A completely symmetrical airfoil will intersect the vertical axis of the graph at the origin (0). A positively cambered airfoil will generate more lift at the same speed (and therefore has a higher CL) than a symmetrical airfoil and therefore intersects the vertical axis above the origin. A negatively cambered airfoil will generate less lift at the same speed (which translates into a lower CL at a certain speed) and therefore intersects the vertical axis below the origin.

content.question: An aeroplane is fitted with an external piece of scientific equipment. Which of the following factors will minimise the increase in form (pressure) drag?

learning.explanation: Fairing - A secondary structure added to any part to reduce its drag. Drag is the force which resists the forward motion of the aircraft. Drag acts parallel to and in the same direction as the relative airflow (in the opposite direction to the flight path). Total Drag is sub-divided into two main types: INDUCED DRAG - the result of lift generation. PARASITE DRAG - independent of lift generation. Parasite drag is further sub-divided into: - Skin Friction Drag - Form (Pressure) Drag - Interference Drag FORM DRAG Form drag is produced whenever the streamline airflow passing over an aircraft separates from the surface and becomes turbulent. An example of extreme form drag is the effect of a flat plate placed at right angles to the airflow. The pressure immediately in front of the plate is above atmospheric, whilst the pressure behind the plate is below atmospheric. This results in a sucking effect behind the plate and the formation of vortices. The more rapidly the airflow changes direction, the greater the pressure gradient, the earlier the separation, and the higher the form drag. Changing the shape, or streamline, of a given object reduces drag by delaying the point at which the airflow separates. On aircraft, for example, a fairing is often fitted around a fixed undercarriage leg to reduce form drag to an acceptable level.

content.question:
Considering subsonic incompressible airflow through a Venturi, which statement is correct?
1. The static pressure in the throat is the same as in the undisturbed airflow.
2. The speed of the airflow in the throat is lower than in the undisturbed airflow.

options.B: 1 is incorrect, 2 is incorrect.
options.C: 1 is correct, 2 is incorrect.
options.D: 1 is correct, 2 is correct.

key_points: To understand the venturi effect, we must first introduce two conditions: The conservation of mass (Continuity Equation) and the Conservation of Energy (Bernoulli’s Theorem)
Conservation of Mass (Continuity Equation) The mass of air entering the pipe, in each unit of time, equals the mass of air leaving the pipe, in the same unit of time
The mass flow through the pipe must remain constant
learning.explanation: To understand the venturi effect, we must first introduce two conditions: The conservation of mass (Continuity Equation) and the Conservation of Energy (Bernoulli’s Theorem). Conservation of Mass (Continuity Equation) The mass of air entering the pipe, in each unit of time, equals the mass of air leaving the pipe, in the same unit of time. The mass flow through the pipe must remain constant. The mass air flow 'm' is the product of the density, the area and the velocity: m= ρ*A*V Continuity equation: m1= m2= m3= ρ1* A1* V1= ρ2* A2* V2= ρ3* A3* V3=constant The continuity equation explains the relationship between velocity and cross-sectional area: The speed is inversely proportional to the cross-sectional area. Conservation of Energy (Bernoulli’s Theorem) The total energy of an airstream comes in two forms: potential energy (static pressure) and kinetic energy (dynamic pressure). The total pressure of the airstream is the sum of the static pressure and the dynamic pressure and must remain constant, according to the law of conservation of energy. Thus, an increase in one form of pressure, must result in a decrease in the other. Dynamic pressure (q) is expressed by: q= 1/2* ρ* V2 Assuming the total pressure to be constant, the static pressure and the dynamic pressure vary inversely: If one increases the other decreases and vice-versa. In Conclusion: With a decrease in section area (from station 1 to station 2), flow speed increases, increasing dynamic pressure. If dynamic pressure increases, static pressure decreases. Statement 1 is therefore incorrect. With a decrease in section area (from station 1 to station 2), flow speed increases, increasing dynamic pressure. Statement 2 is therefore incorrect.

content.question: In ground effect, an aeroplane's effective angle of attack (1) _____ due to the (2) _____ downwash.

options.B: (1) decreases; (2) increased
options.C: (1) decreases; (2) reduced
options.D: (1) increases; (2) reduced

key_points: When an airplane flies at a height equal to or less than the length of its wingspan the efficiency of its wings is considerably improved
A low wing airplane, just before touchdown, can experience up to a 50% reduction of its total drag
This phenomenon is called ground effect
learning.explanation: When an airplane flies at a height equal to or less than the length of its wingspan the efficiency of its wings is considerably improved. A low wing airplane, just before touchdown, can experience up to a 50% reduction of its total drag. This phenomenon is called ground effect. Ground effect occurs because the presence of the nearby ground alters the airflow pattern around the wings. Primarily, the surface restricts the formation of the wingtip vortices and reduces the strength of downwash. When an aircraft enters ground effect, the reduced downwash changes the makeup of the total angle of attack (AoA), by reducing the induced AoA (αi), and therefore increasing the effective AoA (αe). This changes the effective angle of lift, reducing induced drag and increasing lift. Aircraft entering ground effect: Lift increases (if AoA remains constant) The effective angle of attack (αe) increases. The induced angle of attack (αi) decreases. Induced drag decreases. Downwash decreases. Aircraft leaving ground effect: Lift decreases (if AoA remains constant). The effective angle of attack (αe) decreases. The induced angle of attack (αi) increases. Induced drag increases. Downwash increases. Therefore, when entering ground effect, effective angle of attack (αe) increases, due to reduced downwash.

options.B: Only the drag you'd find in a two dimensional flow.

key_points: The total drag is the resulting factor if you add induced drag and parasite drag together
It acts in the direction of the relative wind
Lift is perpendicular to the relative wind
learning.explanation: The total drag is the resulting factor if you add induced drag and parasite drag together. It acts in the direction of the relative wind. Lift is perpendicular to the relative wind. Parasite drag is caused if an airfoil is moving through the air. It is the result of form drag and skin friction drag. Form drag arises from the shape of the object. The more streamlined the object, the less form drag is present. Shape and size are most important in the amount of form drag resulting. Form drag increases with increasing velocity, making it very important for high speed aircraft. Skin friction drag is caused by the friction of the fluid (in case of aircraft this fluid is the atmosphere) against the skin of the object moving through it. It is directly related to the surface area in contact with the fluid. Skin friction increases with the square of the velocity. Parasite drag is made up out of pressure drag, friction drag and interference drag. Parasite drag drag exists even if lift is not being created, (just from the airframe moving through the air). Induced drag, as the name suggests, is a drag produced due to lift.

Plain flaps (figure 1; description a) simply lowers the trailing edge of the wing, increasing camber. It finds primary application in low-speed aircraft and situations where extremely short takeoff and landing distances are not essential. When slotted flaps (figure 2; description c) are deployed, they create a gap or slot between the flap and the wing. This slot is designed to channel higher-pressure air from the lower surface over the flap, revitalizing the boundary layer. By doing so, it postpones airflow separation on the upper surface of the flap. Compared to plain or split flaps, slotted flaps offer a greater increase in CLmax while inducing less drag. Fowler flaps (figure 3; description b) operate by first moving backward and then downward. Initially, they expand the wing area and subsequently enhance its camber. Due to the combined effects of increased area and camber, Fowler flaps provide the most substantial lift augmentation among all flap types. Moreover, they generate minimal drag due to the presence of single or multiple slots and the reduction in thickness-to-chord ratio as the chord length expands. Split flaps (figure 4; description d) are located at the lower surface of the wing's trailing edge, and when lowered, they do not alter the contour of the upper surface. At low angles of attack, they provide a lift increase similar to that of a basic plain flap, but slightly more lift at higher angles. This is because the upper surface's camber remains unchanged, preventing airflow separation. However, the drag is higher than for the plain flap due to the increased depth of the wake.

key_points: The lift from a wing is generated by airflow over it from front to back
If the span-wise flow increases, the boundary layer on the wing surface travels for longer
This causes them to be thicker and more susceptible to transition to turbulence or flow separation
learning.explanation: The lift from a wing is generated by airflow over it from front to back. If the span-wise flow increases, the boundary layer on the wing surface travels for longer. This causes them to be thicker and more susceptible to transition to turbulence or flow separation. The normal tip vortice on a swept wing joins up with a leading edge separation bubble, creating a larger vortex called the Ram’s horn vortex. This vortex goes inboard along the wing’s leading edge. The downward flow from the vortex induces pressure on the boundary layer at the wingtip, whereas on straight wings the exact opposite occurs. With a swept wing, this creates a slow-moving layer of air at the wing tip. This slow-moving air will separate into disturbed flow and will then stall the tip. As the wingtips for a swept wing are positioned aft of the center of pressure (CP), the center of pressure upon a wing tip stall will move forward, creating a nose up moment. This nose up moment will further increase the Angle of Attack if not corrected in time, increasing the layer of slow-moving air, worsening the situation. Due to the decreased downwash on the elevator, the elevator could be less responsive, creating a so called deep stall. Unswept wings do not have this problem. The pitch up phenomenon is a dangerous characteristic of swept wing aircraft (with a T-tail) that move at high speed. It could result in a quickly worsening stalling situation, making it very hard to recover.

content.question: Regarding downwash, which of the following answers is correct?

options.B: The greater the downwash, the less lift is being produced by the aerofoil due to energy loss.
options.C: Downwash is caused by the converging airflow above the aerofoil.
options.D: The greater the downwash, the greater the lift being generated by the aerofoil.

key_points: Please note that downwash can mean two slightly different things
Downwash is the effect of a wing changing the local relative airflow (primarily due to 3D airflow and wingtip vortices)
It is also the term for the air being forced downwards behind a wing as part of lift generation
learning.explanation: Please note that downwash can mean two slightly different things. Downwash is the effect of a wing changing the local relative airflow (primarily due to 3D airflow and wingtip vortices). It is also the term for the air being forced downwards behind a wing as part of lift generation. The terms are very closely linked, and often refer to the same thing, in fact, but there are some differences to how we view them in different contexts as part of the syllabus. The two similar terms do not cause a problem in this question, and the correct answer remains the same. The main wing generates downwash as a by-product of lift generation; the magnitude of downwash is proportional to the lift created. Think of the momentum change in the airflow as being the 'equal and opposite reaction' to the lift force, in order to satisfy Newton's 2nd law of motion. Therefore, one can say that the greater the downwash, the greater the lift being generated by the aerofoil. If the aerofoil is producing more lift, its angle of attack will be greater, and downwash will be greater, especially towards the wingtip where vortices are stronger. If we observe a lot of downwash, we can conclude that a lot of lift is being generated.

learning.explanation: Aircraft are fitted with high lift devices to reduce the take-off and landing distances and improve slow flying characteristics. The three leading edge devices shown in the annex are: Leading Edge Flaps - similar to trailing edge flaps, they increase the camber of the wing to increase CL and CLMAX Kreuger Flaps - part of the lower surface of the leading edge, which can be rotated about its forward edge to force more airflow over the top of the wing at high angles of attack. Slats - These are small "extra leading edges" that move forward in front of the leading edge of the wing, creating a small slot behind, where airflow is sped up and re-energised, delaying the stalling angle of attack without increasing the CL at normal angles of attack. Kreuger Flaps and Slats are often used in conjunction, with Kreuger Flaps being used on the inboard section of an wing and slats being used outboard of the engine pylons, to promote root stall tendency due to the Kreuger Flaps being less effective. They are less common to use on large commercial aircraft than the other leading edge devices, but are used on a few different fighter jets, amongst other aircraft types. This scenario is effectively asking what happens if we land with less flaps. Well of course, with less flaps, our stall speed will be higher, as flaps increase the camber (and sometimes area) of the wing, allowing an aircraft to fly slower with the same amount of lift. key_points: The planform of a wing is a fancy way of saying the shape of the wing when looked on from above

Wings can be made in many different planforms, which all have different properties, ranging from their spanwise lift distributions to their stall characteristics, transonic flight characteristics, ease of construction, etc
Rectangular planforms are the simplest, and this is why small aircraft like Cessna 172s use this planform
learning.explanation: The planform of a wing is a fancy way of saying the shape of the wing when looked on from above. Wings can be made in many different planforms, which all have different properties, ranging from their spanwise lift distributions to their stall characteristics, transonic flight characteristics, ease of construction, etc. Rectangular planforms are the simplest, and this is why small aircraft like Cessna 172s use this planform. They have stable stall characteristics and decent efficiency for small GA and trainer aircraft. Elliptical planforms are the most complex, the most expensive to manufacture, but are mathematically designed to produce the least induced drag. This is because their shape changes the lift distribution to make the root produce more of the lift, and this reduces nicely to zero at the wing tip. This means the air which wishes to go round the wingtip is less prone to doing so, and therefore produces smaller, less impactful wingtip vortices. These smaller wingtip vortices mean that elliptical wings produce less induced drag than other wing planforms. This is part of the reason that they were fitted to some older fighter aeroplanes such as the Supermarine Spitfire, an aircraft that was very reliant on its turning ability, and would therefore experience high induced drag during these manoeuvres. Modern jet aircraft do not use these planforms as they are annoying and expensive to manufacture, and don't have as good high-speed characteristics as swept-tapered wings.

content.question: Which type of aeroplane and situation will experience a larger decrease in induced drag at heights between ground level and a wingspan?

options.A: High wing on take-off
options.B: Low wing on take-off
options.C: High wing on landing
options.D: Low wing on landing

key_points: Short explanation: During landing, a low wing aircraft experiences a reduced amount of lift reduction compared to a high wing aircraft because of its wing's proximity to the ground
This proximity generates a ground effect, which increases lift and reduces drag, resulting in a more stable and controlled landing

In comparison, during takeoff, a high wing aircraft has the advantage of a clearer view of the runway, while a low wing aircraft may have a portion of its wing blocked by the runway surface, reducing lift
learning.explanation: Short explanation: During landing, a low wing aircraft experiences a reduced amount of lift reduction compared to a high wing aircraft because of its wing's proximity to the ground. This proximity generates a ground effect, which increases lift and reduces drag, resulting in a more stable and controlled landing. In comparison, during takeoff, a high wing aircraft has the advantage of a clearer view of the runway, while a low wing aircraft may have a portion of its wing blocked by the runway surface, reducing lift. Ground effect occurs because the surface alters the airflow pattern around the wings. Primarily, the surface restricts the formation of the wingtip vortices. This results in a reduction in the amount of induced downwash behind the wing and increases the wing’s effective angle of attack. THE INFLUENCE OF GROUND EFFECT ON LANDING When an aircraft enters ground effect during the landing phase of flight, the sudden increase in lift and reduction in drag cause it to experience a floating tendency. The aircraft also tends to pitch nose-down due to the reduction in download on the tailplane. THE INFLUENCE OF GROUND EFFECT ON TAKE-OFF During the take-off phase of flight, as the aircraft leaves ground effect the wing tip vortices rapidly grow in magnitude producing an increase in downwash behind the wing. This causes a reduction in the lift produced at a given angle of attack and the associated rapid increase in induced drag may prevent a successful take-off. The increased downwash acting on the tailplane increases the download, resulting in a nose-up pitching moment. Based on the above, we can say that the answer must be one that includes "Landing". Ground effect has greater effect on low wing aircrafts than high wing aircrafts due to being closer to the ground.

learning.explanation: Ground effect basically comes down to how big your wingtip vortices are, and how much downwash they're creating. Take a look at the Cirrus SR-22 examples in the attached figure. Notice the difference in wingtip vortex size at altitude, vs. near the ground? When your wing is close to the ground, wingtip vortices can't get as big, because as they spin around your wingtip, they impact the ground and dissipate. The result? A reduction in downwash. Less downwash, less induced drag. This means that ground effect reduces the coefficient of induced drag (CDI), which is a component of the total drag coefficient (CD). learning.explanation: Wing tip vortices are a byproduct of lift. They are caused by the pressure differential between the top and bottom of the wing, which causes an updraft of high pressure air around the tip of the wing. This updraft turn into a downdraft behind the wing, creating a vortex. The higher the pressure difference between the top and bottom of the wing, the stronger the vortices. This question is specifically asking for: Angle of attack: The strength of the vortices (and therefore also induced drag) is proportional to the angle of attack. Therefore; the strength of the vortices increase as the angle of attack increases. And also; the strength of the vortices decrease as the angle of attack decreases. Therefore statement 1 is incorrect! Aspect ratio: The strength of the vortices is inversely proportional with the aspect ratio. Given a constant load factor, which of these statements about the variation of induced drag with changes of speed and mass are correct or incorrect?

options.A: 1 is correct, 2 is incorrect.
options.B: 1 is incorrect, 2 is correct.
options.C: 1 is incorrect, 2 is incorrect.
options.D: 1 is correct, 2 is correct.

key_points: Induced drag is created as a byproduct of lift
The pressure differential between the top and bottom of the wing creates a upwash around the tip of the wing that turns into a downwash behind the wing
This is known as a vortex, which creates a rearward force known as induced drag
learning.explanation: Induced drag is created as a byproduct of lift. The pressure differential between the top and bottom of the wing creates a upwash around the tip of the wing that turns into a downwash behind the wing. This is known as a vortex, which creates a rearward force known as induced drag. This question is asking for the effect of: Speed: The induced drag is inversely proportional to the speed. Therefore, induced drag increases as the speed decreases, and, induced drag decreases and the speed increases. This is because, to maintain lift constant, as the velocity decreases, the coefficient of lift will have to be increased. At higher coefficients of lift, the pressure differential between the top and bottom of the wing will be greater and therefore produce stronger vortices = stronger induced drag. (and vice versa) Changing mass: Induced drag is proportional to the mass. Therefore, induced drag increases with increasing aeroplane mass, and, induced drag decreases with decreasing aeroplane mass. This is because, as the aircraft get heavier, the lift that the wings will have to produce increases. To achieve that, the coefficient of lift will have to increase, meaning a higher AoA, which creates stronger vortices. (and vice versa) Summary: Higher AR = Lower induced drag Higher AoA = higher induced drag Higher weight = higher AoA = higher induced drag Higher speed = lower AoA = lower induced drag Winglets = lower induced drag.

content.question: Which of the following actions can be taken to reduce the chance of a tail strike during take-off?

options.D: Maintain a steep take-off angle after rotation.

key_points: The two major threats for tail strikes to occur are during the landing flare/touchdown and during rotation on take-off

As many large jet transport aircraft are extended in length for larger passenger numbers, the long tail leaves very little tail margin during rotation, and factors such as crosswinds, gusty head/tailwinds and different weight and CG locations can lead to the potential for reduced tail clearance or tail strike
To mitigate this risk, pilots can choose to rotate at a slightly higher speed, if, for instance, they feel a gust just before rotation that might reduce their airspeed significantly
learning.explanation: The two major threats for tail strikes to occur are during the landing flare/touchdown and during rotation on take-off. As many large jet transport aircraft are extended in length for larger passenger numbers, the long tail leaves very little tail margin during rotation, and factors such as crosswinds, gusty head/tailwinds and different weight and CG locations can lead to the potential for reduced tail clearance or tail strike. To mitigate this risk, pilots can choose to rotate at a slightly higher speed, if, for instance, they feel a gust just before rotation that might reduce their airspeed significantly. A higher airspeed means more airflow over the wings and therefore the aircraft will lift-off at a lower pitch angle, and the tail will therefore be further clear of the ground before reaching the tail strike angle. The pilot could also reduce the rate of rotation to further reduce the chance of tail strikes occurring (as might be done in an engine failure after V1 scenario), but this is not usually recommended in normal operation, and remember that both of these measures are not accounted for in the take-off performance calculation, so be careful not to run out of runway.

The ‘equation of continuity’ states that mass can neither be created nor destroyed; air mass flow is constant. From Bernoulli’s theorem it can be deduced that an increase of airspeed around an aerofoil results in a decrease of air pressure and vice versa. THE STAGNATION POINT The stagnation point is that point on an aerofoil at which the approaching airflow becomes stationary. It is located on the leading edge of the aerofoil just below the maximum point of curvature and moves downward and aft along the lower surface of the aerofoil profile as the angle of attack increases. AEROFOIL UPPER-SURFACE AIRFLOW The flow over the top of the section accelerates rapidly around the nose and over the leading portion of the surface - inducing a substantial decrease in static pressure in those areas. The rate of acceleration increases with increase in angle of attack, up to about 16°. The pressure reduces continuously from the stagnation value through the free stream value to a position on the top surface where a peak negative value is reached. From there onwards the flow continuously slows down again and the pressure increases back to the free stream value in the region of the trailing edge.

key_points: Camber is the asymmetry between two acting surfaces on an airfoil
For an aircraft, this is the top and the bottom of the wing
Positive camber means that a wing is thicker on the top end of the wing, than on the bottom if looked at from the chord
learning.explanation: Camber is the asymmetry between two acting surfaces on an airfoil. For an aircraft, this is the top and the bottom of the wing. Positive camber means that a wing is thicker on the top end of the wing, than on the bottom if looked at from the chord. In case of positive camber, a wing will generate lift with airspeed, as the air on top of the airfoil will get accelerated more than on the bottom, creating a low pressure on the top and high pressure at the bottom. This is “pushing” the wing up into the air as the pressure difference wants to restore itself to 0 difference. In case of negative camber, the exact opposite happens and the lift coefficient for a certain speed is lower than for a positively cambered wing. A completely symmetrical airfoil will intersect the vertical axis of the graph at the origin (0). A positively cambered airfoil will generate more lift at the same speed (and therefore has a higher CL) than a symmetrical airfoil and therefore intersects the vertical axis above the origin. A negatively cambered airfoil will generate less lift at the same speed (which translates into a lower CL at a certain speed) and therefore intersects the vertical axis below the origin.

content.question:
Considering subsonic incompressible airflow through a Venturi, which statement is correct?
1. The static pressure in the throat is lower than in the undisturbed airflow.
2. The speed of the airflow in the throat is lower than in the undisturbed airflow.

options.A: 1 is correct, 2 is incorrect.
options.B: 1 is incorrect, 2 is correct.
options.C: 1 is correct, 2 is correct.
options.D: 1 is incorrect, 2 is incorrect.

key_points: To understand the venturi effect, we must first introduce two conditions: The conservation of mass (Continuity Equation) and the Conservation of Energy (Bernoulli’s Theorem)
Conservation of Mass (Continuity Equation) The mass of air entering the pipe, in each unit of time, equals the mass of air leaving the pipe, in the same unit of time
The mass flow through the pipe must remain constant
learning.explanation: To understand the venturi effect, we must first introduce two conditions: The conservation of mass (Continuity Equation) and the Conservation of Energy (Bernoulli’s Theorem). Conservation of Mass (Continuity Equation) The mass of air entering the pipe, in each unit of time, equals the mass of air leaving the pipe, in the same unit of time. The mass flow through the pipe must remain constant. The mass air flow 'm' is the product of the density, the area and the velocity: m= ρ*A*V Continuity equation: m1= m2= m3= ρ1* A1* V1= ρ2* A2* V2= ρ3* A3* V3=constant The continuity equation explains the relationship between velocity and cross-sectional area: The speed is inversely proportional to the cross-sectional area. Conservation of Energy (Bernoulli’s Theorem) The total energy of an airstream comes in two forms: potential energy (static pressure) and kinetic energy (dynamic pressure). The total pressure of the airstream is the sum of the static pressure and the dynamic pressure and must remain constant, according to the law of conservation of energy. Thus, an increase in one form of pressure, must result in a decrease in the other. Dynamic pressure (q) is expressed by: q= 1/2* ρ* V2 Assuming the total pressure to be constant, the static pressure and the dynamic pressure vary inversely: If one increases the other decreases and vice-versa. In Conclusion: With a decrease in section area (from station 1 to station 2), flow speed increases, increasing dynamic pressure. If dynamic pressure increases, static pressure decreases. Statement 1 is therefore correct. With a decrease in section area (from station 1 to station 2), flow speed increases, increasing dynamic pressure. Statement 2 is therefore incorrect.

options.B: a reduction in air speed, which will cause a decrease in total drag.
options.C: an increase in air speed, which will cause an increase in total drag.
options.D: an increase in air speed, which will cause a decrease in total drag.

key_points: During flight, an aircraft will experience two types of drag: - Parasite Drag (proportional to IAS2, increases with increasing “Parasite Area”: flaps, undercarriage or speed brakes) - Induced Drag (inversely proportional to IAS2, increases with increasing weight)
The sum of Parasite Drag and Induced Drag is the Total Drag
The Total Drag will be minimum at the IAS where Parasite Drag = Induced Drag
learning.explanation: During flight, an aircraft will experience two types of drag: - Parasite Drag (proportional to IAS2, increases with increasing “Parasite Area”: flaps, undercarriage or speed brakes) - Induced Drag (inversely proportional to IAS2, increases with increasing weight). The sum of Parasite Drag and Induced Drag is the Total Drag. The Total Drag will be minimum at the IAS where Parasite Drag = Induced Drag. This speed is called Minimum Drag Speed (VMD). Flying at a slower or faster speed than VMD will generate more drag. Flying at a slower speed than VMD (back side), the aircraft will be in the unstable speed region. Any loss of speed will result in an increase in drag and further speed loss (which must be corrected by an increase in thrust). The sudden change to a tailwind (or a decrease in headwind) will cause a loss of airspeed.

content.question: While performing an obstacle limited take-off, you inadvertently set a lower take-off flap setting (less flap) than the calculated and required. Compared to a take-off at the correct flap setting , the aircraft will pass the departure end of the runway at…

options.B: greater height, as the lower flap setting means that a shorter take-off distance is required.
options.C: lower height, as the lower flap setting means that a greater take-off distance is required.
options.D: lower height, as the lower flap setting means that more drag is generated.

key_points: TRAILING EDGE FLAPS Aircraft are fitted with high lift devices to reduce the take-off and landing distances and when low airspeeds are beneficial
This permits operation at greater weights from given runway lengths and enables greater payloads to be carried
Returning the flaps to their neutral position when no longer required, returns the wing to its former aerodynamic characteristics
learning.explanation: TRAILING EDGE FLAPS Aircraft are fitted with high lift devices to reduce the take-off and landing distances and when low airspeeds are beneficial. This permits operation at greater weights from given runway lengths and enables greater payloads to be carried. Returning the flaps to their neutral position when no longer required, returns the wing to its former aerodynamic characteristics. The increase in lift comes mainly from the variation in effective camber that occurs when the flaps are deflected. This alters the lift curve and also produces a higher maximum coefficient of lift. In some instances, the trailing edge flaps may also increase the wing's surface area. Extending the trailing edge flaps alters the pressure distribution around the wing. USE OF TRAILING EDGE FLAPS FOR TAKE-OFF For take-off purposes, the flaps are normally lowered to a position that provides the best lift-drag ratio that can be obtained with the flaps in any position other than fully up. Since the required lift is obtained at a lower airspeed, the take-off run is also reduced. Larger amounts of flap cause a significant increase in drag, which greatly reduces the acceleration and increases the take-off run. The reduced stalling angle of attack and increased drag associated with flaps also reduces the rate and angle of climb. After take-off, a minimum climb gradient is required in the take-off configuration. Climb gradient is reduced by flap, so if climb gradient is limiting, a lesser flap angle may be selected even though it gives a longer take-off distance.

The EAS at which this occurs is the most economical cruise EAS and varies in direct proportion to the gross mass of the aeroplane. THE EFFECT OF FLAPS Although lift increases with greater flap angles so also does drag, but to a much greater extent, particularly at angles of attack above that which produces the best lift/drag ratio. Lowering flaps usually decreases the lift/drag ratio and, although it is possible to fly at a lower speed, the thrust required increases. learning.explanation: Camber is the asymmetry between two acting surfaces on an airfoil. For an aircraft, this is the top and the bottom of the wing. Positive camber means that a wing is thicker on the top end of the wing, than on the bottom if looked at from the chord. In case of positive camber, a wing will generate lift with airspeed, as the air on top of the airfoil will get accelerated more than on the bottom, creating a low pressure on the top and high pressure at the bottom. This is “pushing” the wing up into the air as the pressure difference wants to restore itself to 0 difference. In case of negative camber, the exact opposite happens and the lift coefficient for a certain speed is lower than for a positively cambered wing. A completely symmetrical airfoil will intersect the vertical axis of the graph at the origin (0). A positively cambered airfoil will generate more lift at the same speed (and therefore has a higher CL) than a symmetrical airfoil and therefore intersects the vertical axis above the origin. A negatively cambered airfoil will generate less lift at the same speed (which translates into a lower CL at a certain speed) and therefore intersects the vertical axis below the origin.

key_points: The total drag is the resulting factor if you add induced drag and parasite drag together
It acts in the direction of the relative wind
Lift is perpendicular to the relative wind
learning.explanation: The total drag is the resulting factor if you add induced drag and parasite drag together. It acts in the direction of the relative wind. Lift is perpendicular to the relative wind. Parasite drag is caused if an airfoil is moving through the air. It is the result of form drag and skin friction drag. Form drag arises from the shape of the object. The more streamlined the object, the less form drag is present. Shape and size are most important in the amount of form drag resulting. Form drag increases with increasing velocity, making it very important for high speed aircraft. Skin friction drag is caused by the friction of the fluid (in case of aircraft this fluid is the atmosphere) against the skin of the object moving through it. It is directly related to the surface area in contact with the fluid. Skin friction increases with the square of the velocity. Parasite drag is made up out of pressure drag, friction drag and interference drag. Induced drag is caused when an object redirects the airflow. A wing produces lift by creating a pressure difference. This pressure difference is caused by the shape of the airfoil, causing the airflow on top to accelerate, creating a low pressure on top of the wing and high pressure below the wing. This pressure difference naturally wants to restore towards a uniform pressure, which creates vortices around the wingtip. These vortices are deflected downwards, this phenomenon is also called downwash. The induced drag decreases with airspeed (with a rate of 1/V²) and increases with angle of attack and increasing weight. In the image we can see that the two vectors (induced and parasite drag) create a resulting vector, the total drag. Where the induced and parasite drag vectors collide, we have the minimum drag speed (VMD); the speed where the total drag is the lowest. This leads us to understand that during an acceleration from a total stand still, the total drag first decreases up until the minimum drag speed and then starts increasing again.

content.question: Considering the airflow around a positively cambered aerofoil that is producing lift, the point of minimum static pressure is found...

options.A: at the point where the chord line originates from the leading edge.
options.B: where the streamlines are closest together.
options.C: slightly below the point at which the chord line originates from the leading edge.
options.D: at the point of maximum camber on the upper surface.

key_points: When considering the pressure, we know that the total pressure always remains constant in subsonic airflow
Next, knowing that the total pressure is equal to the dynamic pressure plus the static pressure, we know that if one increases, the other must decrease to maintain a constant total pressure
Now what is the dynamic pressure and what is static pressure: Dynamic pressure is equal to: q = ½ rho V2
learning.explanation: When considering the pressure, we know that the total pressure always remains constant in subsonic airflow. Next, knowing that the total pressure is equal to the dynamic pressure plus the static pressure, we know that if one increases, the other must decrease to maintain a constant total pressure. Now what is the dynamic pressure and what is static pressure: Dynamic pressure is equal to: q = ½ rho V2. Therefore we can say that the dynamic pressure is proportional to the velocity of the airflow. Static pressure is the pressure that any object feels even when not moving. This pressure is caused by the force of gravity forcing particles closer together and pushing against each other and any objects around them. Knowing that dynamic pressure is basically the velocity of the airflow, we can say that if the velocity increase, hence increasing the dynamic pressure, there has to be a reduction in static pressure. This is known as Bernoulli’s principle! Therefore, going back to the question, we can say that the point of minimum static pressure is the point of maximum dynamic pressure (airflow velocity). Therefore the point of minimum static pressure will be somewhere on the top of a positively cambered aerofoil. This would most commonly be at the point of maximum camber, but not always! Changes in angle of attack will move the point of maximum velocity forwards and backwards, therefore the most correct answer is where streamlines are closest together.

key_points: Wing tip vortices are a byproduct of lift
They are caused by the pressure differential between the top and bottom of the wing, which causes an updraft of high pressure air around the tip of the wing
This updraft turns into a downdraft behind the wing, creating a vortex
learning.explanation: Wing tip vortices are a byproduct of lift. They are caused by the pressure differential between the top and bottom of the wing, which causes an updraft of high pressure air around the tip of the wing. This updraft turns into a downdraft behind the wing, creating a vortex. The higher the pressure difference between the top and bottom of the wing, the stronger the vortices. This question is specifically asking for: Angle of attack: The strength of the vortices (and therefore also induced drag) is proportional to the angle of attack. Therefore; the strength of the vortices increase as the angle of attack increases, hence statement 1 is incorrect! Aspect ratio: The strength of the vortices is inversely proportional with the aspect ratio. Meaning that the strength of the wing tip vortices decreases as the aspect ratio increases, hence statement 2 is incorrect!

key_points: Drag is the force which resists the forward motion of the aircraft
Drag acts parallel to and in the same direction as the relative airflow (in the opposite direction to the flight path)
Total Drag is sub-divided into two main types: Parasite Drag - independent of lift generation Induced Drag - the result of lift generation
learning.explanation: Drag is the force which resists the forward motion of the aircraft. Drag acts parallel to and in the same direction as the relative airflow (in the opposite direction to the flight path). Total Drag is sub-divided into two main types: Parasite Drag - independent of lift generation Induced Drag - the result of lift generation. Parasite drag is further sub-divided into: - Skin Friction Drag - Form (Pressure) Drag - Interference Drag FORM DRAG Form (pressure) drag results from the pressure at the leading edge of a body being greater than the pressure at the trailing edge. Skin friction, along with the adverse pressure gradient behind the transition will cause a reduction in kinetic energy of the boundary layer. Separation will occur when the boundary layer does not have sufficient kinetic energy in the presence of a given adverse pressure gradient. Because of separation, there will be a lower pressure at the trailing edge than the leading edge. An aerodynamic force will act in the direction of the lower pressure - form drag. When a shock wave forms on the upper surface, the increase of static pressure through the shock wave will create an extreme adverse pressure gradient. If the shock wave is sufficiently strong, separation will occur immediately behind the shock wave.

Increasing the camber of an aerofoil section increases the CL at a given angle of attack and increases CLMAX
TRAILING EDGE FLAPS Aircraft are fitted with high lift devices to reduce the take-off and landing distances and when low airspeeds are beneficial
learning.explanation: CLMAX AUGMENTATION One of the main factors which determine the CLMAX of an aerofoil section is the camber. Increasing the camber of an aerofoil section increases the CL at a given angle of attack and increases CLMAX. TRAILING EDGE FLAPS Aircraft are fitted with high lift devices to reduce the take-off and landing distances and when low airspeeds are beneficial. This permits operation at greater weights from given runway lengths and enables greater payloads to be carried. The increase in lift comes mainly from the variation in effective camber that occurs when the flaps are deflected. This alters the lift curve and also produces a higher maximum coefficient of lift. In some instances, the trailing edge flaps may also increase the wing's surface area. Extending the trailing edge flaps alters the pressure distribution around the wing. USE OF TRAILING EDGE FLAPS FOR TAKE-OFF For take-off purposes, the flaps are normally lowered to a position that provides the best lift-drag ratio that can be obtained with the flaps in any position other than fully up. Since the required lift is obtained at a lower airspeed, the take-off run is also reduced. Larger amounts of flap cause a significant increase in drag, which greatly reduces the acceleration and increases the take-off run. The reduced stalling angle of attack and increased drag associated with flaps also reduces the rate and angle of climb.

content.question: What is correct about wingtip vortices? They are...

options.A: Stronger with a high aspect ratio.
options.B: Stronger in clean configuration.
options.C: Not related to aspect ratio.
options.D: Stronger at high speed.

key_points: WING-TIP VORTICES Wing-tip vortices are created by span-wise airflow over the upper and lower surfaces of a wing/aerofoil that meet at the wing tips as turbulence and therefore induces drag
Span-wise airflow is created because a wing producing lift has a lower static pressure on the upper surface than on the lower surface

At the wing tip, however, there can be no pressure difference, and the pressure is equalized by air flowing around the wing tip from the higher pressure on the lower surface to the lower pressure on the upper surface
learning.explanation: WING-TIP VORTICES Wing-tip vortices are created by span-wise airflow over the upper and lower surfaces of a wing/aerofoil that meet at the wing tips as turbulence and therefore induces drag. Span-wise airflow is created because a wing producing lift has a lower static pressure on the upper surface than on the lower surface. At the wing tip, however, there can be no pressure difference, and the pressure is equalized by air flowing around the wing tip from the higher pressure on the lower surface to the lower pressure on the upper surface. There is therefore a span-wise pressure gradient, i.e., pressure changing along the wing span. One of the primary factors which determine the magnitude of the vortices is the angle of attack. For a given speed, the wing lift, and thus the magnitude of the tip vortices, increases with the angle of attack. Slow, heavy, clean" are the three major conditions generating stronger wing vortices. Extending the flaps increases the coefficient of lift (CL), which means that for a given speed, a lower angle of attack will be required, which reduces the wing tip vortices strength. “Stronger with a high aspect ratio” and “Not related to aspect ratio”. Incorrect. The magnitude of the wingtip vortices is inversely proportional to aspect ratio
