This helps you visualise the scenario, but in reality, even that knowledge is not required. If an aerofoil is not producing any lift, then it is not producing any lift-induced drag, which is a by-product of lift. key_points: In an aircraft, spoilers can be installed to intentionally reduce lift and increase drag for a specific wing by partially disrupting the airflow over the airfoil
They can extend symmetrically or asymmetrically
If spoilers on both sides are used, its primary purpose is to reduce the speed at which the aircraft is travelling
learning.explanation: In an aircraft, spoilers can be installed to intentionally reduce lift and increase drag for a specific wing by partially disrupting the airflow over the airfoil. They can extend symmetrically or asymmetrically. If spoilers on both sides are used, its primary purpose is to reduce the speed at which the aircraft is travelling. Spoilers can also be used in a turn to assist the ailerons. In this case, the spoiler mounted on the down-going wing will come up, reducing lift for that wing even more and therefore assisting the ailerons. The spoiler on the up-moving wing will remain stowed. For example, if the aircraft wants to enter a right turn, it will have to bank to the right. The right wing will have to come down and the left wing will have to rise. The aileron on the left will come down, producing more lift on the left wing and the aileron on the right will come up. The spoiler mounted on the upper side of the right wing will also come up, reducing lift of the right wing even more. This way the aircraft reaches its desired bank angle easier at low speeds.

content.question: Whilst setting up for landing, the crew are distracted by an external event on the radio. In doing so, they forget to set the final stage of flaps. The aircraft system automatically adjusts the approach speed for the reduced flap setting, but does not notify the pilots, so they land with a lower flap setting (less flaps) than planned and computed. The landing distance will (1) _____ due to (2) _____ and (3)_____ being generated by the lower flap setting, and therefore a (4) _____ touchdown speed.

options.A: (1) increase; (2) less drag; (3) less lift; (4) higher
options.B: (1) increase; (2) less drag; (3) more lift; (4) lower
options.C: (1) decrease; (2) less drag; (3) less lift; (4) lower
options.D: (1) increase; (2) more drag; (3) more lift; (4) higher

key_points: Note: This is similar to question 812314, but includes more/less drag as an option
This has been seen as a drop-down menu question in the UK CAA exams
Learning Objective 081
learning.explanation: Note: This is similar to question 812314, but includes more/less drag as an option. This has been seen as a drop-down menu question in the UK CAA exams. Learning Objective 081.01.09.01.09: Explain the effects of flap-setting errors, such as mis-selection and premature/late extension or retraction of flaps, on: take-off and landing distance and speeds; climb and descent performance; stall buffet margins. This scenario is effectively asking what happens if we land with less flaps. Well of course, with less flaps, our stall speed will be higher, as flaps increase the camber (and sometimes area) of the wing, allowing an aircraft to fly slower with the same amount of lift. With a higher stall speed, the approach speed VREF will be higher, the aircraft will touch down with more groundspeed, causing a longer landing distance than if a higher flap setting were to be used. So that is (1) and (4) answered, and we must remember that with a lower flap setting we have less lift available for the same IAS. This is the component that influences our landing distance, as the lack of lift means we have to fly at a higher speed, and land at a higher speed. As for the drag, lower flap settings produce less drag. This is not the main factor behind the increased landing distance though, as most of the braking action during landing comes from the brakes (and reverse thrust, if available), and the flaps actually reduce the weight of the aircraft on the wheels, so reduce braking ability slightly.

content.question: Assuming incompressible flow, when considering streamlines in the vicinity of an aerofoil, which of the following answers is correct?

options.A: Converging streamlines indicate that the speed of the flow is increasing and that the static pressure is decreasing.
options.B: Diverging streamlines indicate that the speed of the flow is decreasing and that the static pressure is decreasing.
options.C: Diverging streamlines indicate that the speed of the flow is increasing and that the static pressure is increasing.
options.D: Converging streamlines indicate that the speed of the flow is decreasing and that the static pressure is increasing.

key_points: When considering streamlines, we can say that converging streamlines indicate an increasing airflow velocity, and diverging lines indicate a decreasing airflow velocity
Now when considering the pressure, we know that the total pressure always remains constant in subsonic airflow
Next, knowing that the total pressure is equal to the dynamic pressure plus the static pressure, we know that if one increases, the other must decrease to maintain a constant total pressure
learning.explanation: When considering streamlines, we can say that converging streamlines indicate an increasing airflow velocity, and diverging lines indicate a decreasing airflow velocity. Now when considering the pressure, we know that the total pressure always remains constant in subsonic airflow. Next, knowing that the total pressure is equal to the dynamic pressure plus the static pressure, we know that if one increases, the other must decrease to maintain a constant total pressure. Now what is the dynamic pressure and what is static pressure: Dynamic pressure is equal to: q = ½ rho V2. Therefore we can say that the dynamic pressure is proportional to the velocity of the airflow. Static pressure is the pressure that any object feels even when not moving. This pressure is caused by the force of gravity forcing particles closer together and pushing against each other and any objects around them. Knowing that dynamic pressure is basically the velocity of the airflow, we can say that if the velocity increase, hence increasing the dynamic pressure, there has to be a reduction in static pressure. This is known as Bernoulli’s principle! What this means for our question is that: Converging streamlines indicate a speed increase Diverging streamlines indicated a speed decrease A decrease in static pressure occurs with an increasing speed And an increase in static pressure occurs with a decreasing speed

learning.explanation: To explain, lets compare all the answers and see why each is correct or incorrect. 1) Boundary layer separation on the aft portion of the wing. – Incorrect Boudary layer separation is a normal phenomenon that occurs during flight. This has nothing to do with induced drag. 2) Propeller slipstream over the wing. – Incorrect The slipstream from a propeller will cause a couple effects, such as yaw, and torque, but it will have no effect on induced drag. 3) Aerodynamic interaction between aeroplane parts. – Incorrect The drag because of aerodynamic interaction between aeroplane parts is known as interfrerence drag, and has nothing to do with induced drag. 4) Downwash generated by tip vortices. – Correct Firstly, one could simply deduce the correct answer through cancelling out the incorrect answer. content.question: At a load factor of 1 and the aeroplane's minimum drag speed, what is the ratio between induced drag DI and parasite drag DP?

options.A: DI / DP = 2.
options.B: DI / DP = 1 / 2.
options.C: DI / DP = 1.

key_points: The total drag is the resulting factor if you add induced drag and parasite drag together
Parasite drag is caused if an airfoil is moving through the air
It is the result of form drag and skin friction drag
learning.explanation: The total drag is the resulting factor if you add induced drag and parasite drag together. Parasite drag is caused if an airfoil is moving through the air. It is the result of form drag and skin friction drag. Form drag arises from the shape of the object The more streamlined the object, the less form drag is present. Shape and size are most important in the amount of form drag resulting. Form drag increases with increasing velocity, making it very important for high speed aircraft. Skin friction drag is caused by the friction of the fluid (in case of aircraft this fluid is the atmosphere) against the skin of the object moving through it. It is directly related to the surface area in contact with the fluid. Skin friction increases with the square of the velocity. Induced drag is caused when an object redirects the airflow. A wing produces lift by creating a pressure difference. This pressure difference is caused by the shape of the airfoil, causing the airflow on top to accelerate, creating a low pressure on top of the wing and high pressure below the wing. This pressure difference naturally wants to restore towards a uniform pressure, which creates vortices around the wingtip. These vortices are deflected downwards, this phenomenon is also called downwash. The induced drag decreases with airspeed and increases with angle of attack and increasing weight. In the image we can see that the two vectors (induced and parasite drag) create a resulting vector, the total drag. Where the induced and parasite drag vectors collide, we have the minimum drag speed (VMD); the speed where the total drag is the lowest. This leads us to understand that during an acceleration from a total stand still, the total drag first decreases up until the minimum drag speed and then starts increasing again.

Parasite drag is further sub-divided into: Skin Friction Drag Form (Pressure) Drag, and Interference Drag NOTE: Skin Friction and Form Drag are together known as PROFILE DRAG. Boundary Layer Skin friction drag is a function of the layer of air closest to the surface. As air flows over a wing, the roughness of the surface and the viscous property of the air itself slow it down. Much like fluids, the more viscous the air, the greater its retardation. At the surface, the air particles adhere to it and their relative velocity is reduced to zero (figure 1). Just above the surface, the air particles slow down due to the friction effects between the particles, but except for the layer in contact with the surface, the particles do not completely come to rest. The relative velocity of the air particles increases steadily with distance from the surface, until reaching a point where the particles do not slow up at all and instead travel at the free stream velocity. The boundary layer is the layer of air between the surface and the free stream velocity in which local retardation takes place. Like the main airflow, the boundary layer flow can be either laminar or turbulent in nature (figure 2). Skin Friction Drag Skin friction is the reaction to the retardation of the airflow within the boundary layer. The retarded air tries to drag the surface along with the flow, in much the same way as two solid surfaces sliding over each other do. Known as shear stress, this is directly proportional to the speed of flow. Figure 3 represents the shear stress patterns that exist between layers. The gradual velocity change associated with the laminar boundary layer shows that low shear stresses exist near the surface, resulting in low skin friction drag. Conversely, the rapid velocity change associated with the turbulent boundary layer is evidence of high skin friction drag.

content.question: Which plane and situation experiences the least amount of lift reduction?

options.A: High wing on take-off
options.B: Low wing on take-off
options.C: High wing on landing

key_points: Ground effect occurs because the surface alters the airflow pattern around the wings
Primarily, the surface restricts the formation of the wingtip vortices
This results in a reduction in the amount of induced downwash behind the wing and increases the wing’s effective angle of attack
learning.explanation: Ground effect occurs because the surface alters the airflow pattern around the wings. Primarily, the surface restricts the formation of the wingtip vortices. This results in a reduction in the amount of induced downwash behind the wing and increases the wing’s effective angle of attack. It also alters the pressure distribution around the wing and the amount of lift developed. This occurs because the change in effective angle of attack increases the wing’s coefficient of lift (CL) and thus its lifting capability at any given angle of attack. The magnitude of the wing tip vortices, and thus downwash, also determine the amount of induced drag produced by the wing. The closer the aircraft is to the surface, the greater the reduction in induced drag at any given angle of attack. (figure 2) THE INFLUENCE OF GROUND EFFECT ON LANDING When an aircraft enters ground effect during the landing phase of flight, the sudden increase in lift and reduction in drag cause it to experience a floating tendency. The aircraft also tends to pitch nose-down due to the reduction in download on the tailplane. THE INFLUENCE OF GROUND EFFECT ON TAKE-OFF During the take-off phase of flight, as the aircraft leaves ground effect the wing tip vortices rapidly grow in magnitude producing an increase in downwash behind the wing. This causes a reduction in the lift produced at a given angle of attack and the associated rapid increase in induced drag may prevent a successful take-off. The increased downwash acting on the tailplane increases the download, resulting in a nose-up pitching moment. The high wing aircraft will still experience ground effect, but because the wing is several feet farther from the runway, the total effect on the aircraft is greatly reduced, as ground effect decreases exponentially with difference from the runway surface. Thus, a high wing on take-off is the configuration with the least reduction in lift.

learning.explanation: For a fixed wing aircraft, ground effect is the increased lift and decreased drag that the wings generate when they are close to the ground. This means that the aircraft needs a lower angle of attack for a certain amount of lift. This results in lower induced drag (decreasing induced angle of attack).

learning.explanation: An alternative to increasing the angle of attack to increase lift is to lower trailing-edge flaps provided the speed is at or below the maximum speed for lowering flap (VFO). This effectively increases the camber of the wing, the angle of attack and the coefficient of lift. However, the thrust may have to be increased to overcome the increased drag, even though when deployed they decrease the magnitude of the wing-tip vortices. Not only does the extension of trailing-edge flaps decrease the critical angle of attack it also increases the CLMAX, increases the total lift generated, increases the total drag, unfavorably affects the lift/drag ratio and decreases the stalling speed no matter what the altitude or mass of the airplane. Unlike slats, trailing-edge flaps increase lift at all angles of attack up to the stall. Thus, if the angle of attack remains constant during flap extension the airplane will begin to climb. All trailing-edge flaps when lowered, increase the acceleration of the airflow over the upper surface of the wing, which reduces the pressure above the wing and increases the upwash over the leading edge. Together these influences generate an increased nose-down pitching moment because of the altered pressure distribution around the flaps and the aft movement of the wing CP.

content.question: While flying under icing conditions, the largest ice build-up will occur, principally, on:

options.B: the pitot and static probes only.
options.C: the upper and lower rudder surfaces.

key_points: The formation of ice and frost on the airframe will: - modify the profile of the aerofoil
- increase the roughness of the aircraft surface
- increase the weight of the aircraft
learning.explanation: The formation of ice and frost on the airframe will: - modify the profile of the aerofoil. - increase the roughness of the aircraft surface. - increase the weight of the aircraft. Ice will normally form on and around the leading edges of wings and tailplane and can result in severe distortion of the leading edge profile. This will give a large increase in drag and a substantial decrease in CLMAX. The skin friction drag will increase and the boundary layer will have an earlier separation, giving a reduced critical angle of attack, thereby a higher stall speed. Ice builds up on an aircraft when the super-cooled water droplets (SCWDs) hit the cold airframe and freeze onto the surface. This will happen most in particular sections of the aircraft, such as the leading edges of the wings, the nose, propeller spinners, the tail leading edges, and any protrusions such as the windshield, pitot tubes, AoA vanes, etc. This effect is much more pronounced when the items are sharp, instead of curved. Take a wing for example: when it is a very curved wing, useful for low speed flight, it will have a leading edge with a large radius, and the pressure waves that propagate from the front of the wing during flight are effectively giving the air advanced warming that the wing is coming, so it can move out of the way. This means that the SCWDs also move out of the way, so do not hit the wing as much. This means that sharp wings (with a smaller radius - used for higher speed flight) give less of a "warning" to the air, and the SCWDs will not move out of the way as much, thereby causing more ice accretion. This is the same for sharp protrusions such as the AoA vanes and pitot tubes.

An ice-contaminated wing will stall at a lower angle of attack (decreased critical AOA) or higher airspeed (increased stall speed) than a clean wing

learning.explanation: Any deposit of ice, snow or frost on the external surfaces of an aeroplane, except as permitted in the flight manual, may drastically affect its performance due to reduced aerodynamic lift and increased drag resulting from the disturbed airflow. An ice-contaminated wing will stall at a lower angle of attack (decreased critical AOA) or higher airspeed (increased stall speed) than a clean wing. Minute amounts of ice (equivalent to medium grit sandpaper) covering the leading edges or upper surfaces of wings can increase the stall speed up to 15 kt. Ice will also increase the weight and, therefore the stall speed also increases, because a higher angle of attack is required to produce an increased lift. content.question:
Refer to figure.
The diagram shows the parameter X against TAS. If horizontal flight is considered axis X represents:

options.A: the parasite drag.
options.B: the total drag.
options.C: the lift force.
options.D: the induced drag.

key_points: The total drag is the resulting factor if you add induced drag and parasite drag together
Parasite drag is caused if an airfoil is moving through the air
It is the result of form drag and skin friction drag
learning.explanation: The total drag is the resulting factor if you add induced drag and parasite drag together. Parasite drag is caused if an airfoil is moving through the air. It is the result of form drag and skin friction drag. Form drag arises from the shape of the object. The more streamlined the object, the less form drag is present. Shape and size are most important in the amount of form drag resulting. Form drag increases with increasing velocity, making it very important for high speed aircraft. Skin friction drag is caused by the friction of the fluid (in case of aircraft this fluid is the atmosphere) against the skin of the object moving through it. It is directly related to the surface area in contact with the fluid. Skin friction increases with the square of the velocity. Induced drag is caused when an object redirects the airflow. A wing produces lift by creating a pressure difference. This pressure difference is caused by the shape of the airfoil, causing the airflow on top to accelerate, creating a low pressure on top of the wing and high pressure below the wing. This pressure difference naturally wants to restore towards a uniform pressure, which creates vortices around the wingtip. These vortices are deflected downwards, this phenomenon is also called downwash. The induced drag decreases with airspeed and increases with angle of attack and increasing weight. In the image we can see that the two vectors (induced and parasite drag) create a resulting vector, the total drag. Where the induced and parasite drag vectors collide, we have the minimum drag speed (VMD); the speed where the total drag is the lowest. This leads us to understand that during an acceleration from a total stand still, the total drag first decreases up until the minimum drag speed and then starts increasing again.

key_points: Be careful with this question! Mass flow can be defined by: Mass flow rate = density x velocity x cross section are And we know that: Mass flow rate = constant Assuming constant velocity, we can say that an increase in temperature will decrease the air density and therefore decrease the mass flow

Now let’s create a situation that follows all the specified parameters of the question
learning.explanation: Be careful with this question! Mass flow can be defined by: Mass flow rate = density x velocity x cross section are And we know that: Mass flow rate = constant Assuming constant velocity, we can say that an increase in temperature will decrease the air density and therefore decrease the mass flow. However this question does not specify that the velocity remains constant. Now let’s create a situation that follows all the specified parameters of the question. Let’s say we have a tube with steady low subsonic flow. Halfway through this pipe we have a heating element that heats up the air, this will decrease the density of the airflow. So that means we have less mass flow right? Well no because mass flow will naturally always keep itself constant, therefore if the density of the air decreases without any change in cross section area, the velocity will increase. This is because the mass flow on the entry side of the tube will always be the same as the mass flow on the exit side of the tube, even if the air is warmer/colder. Therefore, assuming no constant velocity is specified, any change in temperature will not affect the flow rate.

Please send any further exam feedback to us in the comments or by email to info@atplquestions.com, thank you. Learning Objective 081.01.10.01.02: Describe the effect of spoilers on the CL-alpha graph and stall speed. Spoilers are aerodynamic surfaces that exist on the top surface of some wings, and are used for many reasons. They are primarily used to increase drag and "dump" lift. (If they are just for drag then they are called speedbrakes, but aircraft manufacturers do blur these distinctions). They are called spoilers because they "spoil" the airflow, sticking up into the airflow, causing a lift reduction similar to an up-going aileron and a similar drag increase to that of a split flap. Of course, the spoiled airflow is not as effective at producing lift, and the CLMAX of wings with spoilers extended is much lower, so the stall speed therefore increases. The effect on the critical angle of attack is much more complicated, however, and is not always easy to predict. As the spoiler pushes up into the airflow, the adverse pressure gradient over it (which usually causes the stall) is reduced and the airflow is re-energised, but the area behind the spoiler (most do not go all the way to the trailing edge of the wing) is automatically stalled after a small spoiler deflection, due to the gap created. So there are two opposing forces at play: Spoilers act a little bit like an up-going aileron, re-energising the airflow and increasing the critical AoA, The large stalled area behind the spoiler decreases the critical AoA. Therefore, it is difficult to say what effect spoiler deflection will have on the critical AoA. Some sources mention a slight decrease in critical AoA overall, but it appears that EASA have published other questions where the overall effect is an increase in the critical AoA due to spoiler extension, so we have stuck with this across all questions, as it seems likely that the examiner wants this answer (and feedback has agreed with this in the past). In this case though, the graph given in the question removes all uncertainty, and an increase in critical AoA is the only possible correct answer. Of course, the real answer is certain to depend on the proportion of the wing, the size and location of the spoiler, and most importantly, the amount of spoiler deflection. As this is so complex, the examiner’s choice of answer is all that truly matters here.

When a flap is deflected downwards, the camber of the airfoil increases, the coefficient of lift (CL) increases, resulting in higher lift production. learning.explanation: Speedbrakes (flight spoilers) are secondary flight control surfaces that can be deployed manually by the pilot. Dependent upon the aircraft type, the speed brake(s) may consist of a single panel or symetrically mounted pairs of panels. In most cases, speedbrakes are panels (most frequently on the upper surface of the wing, but sometimes mounted on the fuselage top side or left/right side near the tail) which, when selected by the pilot, extend into the airstream to produce drag. Their operating principle is simple. Cross-sectional area increases, the air becomes turbulent in the space directly behind them, which increases parasite drag. The wing-mounted versions of speedbrakes also dump some lift and thereby increase induced drag also as the wing has to fly at a higher angle of attack (though not all speed brakes are of this type, so it is not the correct answer). options.B: High wing at landing.

key_points: Ground effect occurs because the surface alters the airflow pattern around the wings
Primarily, the surface restricts the formation of the wingtip vortices
This results in a reduction in the amount of induced downwash behind the wing and increases the wing’s effective angle of attack
learning.explanation: Ground effect occurs because the surface alters the airflow pattern around the wings. Primarily, the surface restricts the formation of the wingtip vortices. This results in a reduction in the amount of induced downwash behind the wing and increases the wing’s effective angle of attack. It also alters the pressure distribution around the wing and the amount of lift developed. This occurs because the change in effective angle of attack increases the wing’s coefficient of lift (CL) and thus its lifting capability at any given angle of attack. THE INFLUENCE OF GROUND EFFECT ON LANDING When an aircraft enters ground effect during the landing phase of flight, the sudden increase in lift and reduction in drag cause it to experience a floating tendency. The aircraft also tends to pitch nose-down due to the reduction in download on the tailplane. THE INFLUENCE OF GROUND EFFECT ON TAKE-OFF During the take-off phase of flight, as the aircraft leaves ground effect the wing tip vortices rapidly grow in magnitude producing an increase in downwash behind the wing. This causes a reduction in the lift produced at a given angle of attack and the associated rapid increase in induced drag may prevent a successful take-off. The increased downwash acting on the tailplane increases the download, resulting in a nose-up pitching moment. The magnitude of the wing tip vortices, and thus downwash, determine the amount of induced drag produced by the wing. The closer the aircraft is to the surface, the greater the reduction in induced drag at any given angle of attack. Thus, a low wing aircraft on landing will produce the least amount of Induced Drag. content.question: According to the equation of continuity, the constant mass flow in a stream tube is dependent on the following for a low subsonic flow, assuming that the air is incompressible:

options.A: Velocity of the air only
options.B: Velocity of the air and cross-sectional area of the stream tube

key_points: To demonstrate the effect the Principle of Continuity has on aerodynamic theory, we consider a streamline flow of air through a tube, which has a reduced cross-sectional area in the middle
The air mass flow, or mass per unit time (kg/m3), through the tube will be the product of the cross-sectional area (A), the airflow velocity (V), and the air density (ρ)
Mass flow will remain a constant value at all points along the tube
learning.explanation: To demonstrate the effect the Principle of Continuity has on aerodynamic theory, we consider a streamline flow of air through a tube, which has a reduced cross-sectional area in the middle. The air mass flow, or mass per unit time (kg/m3), through the tube will be the product of the cross-sectional area (A), the airflow velocity (V), and the air density (ρ). Mass flow will remain a constant value at all points along the tube. The equation of continuity is: A x V x ρ = Constant Because air is a compressible fluid, any pressure change in the flow will affect the air density. However, at low subsonic speeds (< M 0.4 or Mach 0.4, i.e., aircraft speed is 40% of the local speed of sound), density changes will be insignificant and can be disregarded. The equation of continuity can now be simplified to: A x V = Constant ⇒ V ≈ 1/A Because the mass flow must remain constant, it can be seen from the equation of continuity that the reduction in the tube’s cross-sectional area results in an increase in velocity, and vice versa.

Form drag is produced whenever the streamline airflow passing over an aircraft separates from the surface and becomes turbulent. An example of extreme form drag is the effect of a flat plate placed at right angles to the airflow. The pressure immediately in front of the plate is above atmospheric, whilst the pressure behind the plate is below atmospheric. The more rapidly the airflow changes direction, the greater the pressure gradient, the earlier the separation, and the higher the form drag. Changing the shape, or streamline, of a given object reduces drag by delaying the point at which the airflow separates.

key_points: The formation of ice and frost on the airframe will: - modify the profile of the aerofoil

- increase the weight of the aircraft
learning.explanation: The formation of ice and frost on the airframe will: - modify the profile of the aerofoil. - increase the roughness of the aircraft surface. - increase the weight of the aircraft. The CL of an aerofoil increases with angle of attack up to a maximum (CLMAX). Any further increase above this stalling angle, or critical angle of attack, will make it impossible for the airflow to smoothly follow the upper wing contour, and the flow will separate from the surface, causing CL to decrease and drag to increase rapidly. A stall is caused by airflow separation. Separation can occur when either the boundary layer has insufficient kinetic energy or the adverse pressure gradient becomes too great. The formation of ice along a wing's leading edge greatly alters its aerodynamic contour and leads to premature separation of the boundary layer. This reduces the wing's stalling angle of attack and also its maximum coefficient of lift by up to 50% The increase in stall speed due to ice formation is not easy to quantify, as the accumulation and shape of the iceformation is impossible to predict. Ice or frost must never be allowed to remain on any aerodynamic surfaces in flight, nor must ice, frost, snow or other contamination be allowed to remain on the aircraft immediately before flight.

key_points: Induced drag is created as a byproduct of lift
The pressure differential between the top and bottom of the wing creates a upwash around the tip of the wing that turns into a downwash behind the wing
This is known as a vortex, which creates a rearward force known as induced drag
learning.explanation: Induced drag is created as a byproduct of lift. The pressure differential between the top and bottom of the wing creates a upwash around the tip of the wing that turns into a downwash behind the wing. This is known as a vortex, which creates a rearward force known as induced drag. The shape of an airfoil has a huge impact on the induced drag of an aircraft assuming the same weight and speed. This question is asking for the effect of: Lift distribution: An elliptical lift distribution generates less induced drag than a rectangular lift distribution. This is because the lift distribution of a rectangular wing creates a larger force near the tip. Even though the elliptical wing creates a larger coefficient of lift at the tip, the subsequently smaller wing area near the tip means that barely any force of lift is created there any therefore leads to a smaller vortex and less induced drag. Therefore statement 1 is correct! Aspect ratio: Induced drag is inversely proportional to the aspect ratio. Therefore, induced drag increases with decreasing aspect ratio, and, induced drag decreases with increasing aspect ratio. Therefore statement 2 is incorrect!

learning.explanation: Any deposit of ice, snow or frost on the external surfaces of an aeroplane, except as permitted in the flight manual, may drastically affect its performance due to reduced aerodynamic lift and increased drag resulting from the disturbed airflow. An ice-contaminated wing will stall at a lower angle of attack (decreased critical AOA) or higher airspeed (increased stall speed) than a clean wing. Minute amounts of ice (equivalent to medium grit sandpaper) covering the leading edges or upper surfaces of wings can increase the stall speed up to 15 kt. Ice will also increase the weight and, therefore the stall speed also increases, because a higher angle of attack is required to produce an increased lift. options.B: IAS would increase due to the increased drag.
options.C: IAS would increase due to the decreased drag.
options.D: IAS would further decrease due to the decreased drag.

key_points: During flight, an aircraft will experience two types of drag: - Parasite Drag (proportional to IAS2, increases with increasing “Parasite Area”: flaps, undercarriage or speed brakes) - Induced Drag (inversely proportional to IAS2, increases with increasing weight)
The sum of Parasite Drag and Induced Drag is the Total Drag
The Total Drag will be minimum at the IAS where Parasite Drag = Induced Drag
learning.explanation: During flight, an aircraft will experience two types of drag: - Parasite Drag (proportional to IAS2, increases with increasing “Parasite Area”: flaps, undercarriage or speed brakes) - Induced Drag (inversely proportional to IAS2, increases with increasing weight). The sum of Parasite Drag and Induced Drag is the Total Drag. The Total Drag will be minimum at the IAS where Parasite Drag = Induced Drag. This speed is called Minimum Drag Speed (VMD). Flying at a slower or faster speed than VMD will generate more drag. Flying at a slower speed than VMD (back side), the aircraft will be in the unstable speed region. Any loss of speed will result in an increase in drag and further speed loss (which must be corrected by an increase in thrust). The sudden change to a tailwind (or a decrease in headwind) can cause a loss of airspeed. Flying at a faster speed than VMD (front side), the aircraft will be in the stable speed region. Any loss of speed will result in an decrease in drag. This decrease in drag will allow the speed to increase and recover the original speed. The sudden change to a tailwind (or a decrease in headwind) can cause a loss of airspeed.

key_points: SYMMETRICAL AEROFOIL The distribution of pressure is important in aerodynamics, since it determines: - The amount of lift generated - Any pitching moments - The form drag of an aerofoil section The lift and drag forces of a wing cross-section are dependent on the pressure distribution around the wing
The pressure distribution around an aerofoil is the resultant of the angle of the aerofoil chordline to the oncoming airflow, the angle of attack
If a symmetrical aerofoil section is in a steady airstream at zero degrees Angle of Attack, a stagnation point forms on the leading edge
learning.explanation: SYMMETRICAL AEROFOIL The distribution of pressure is important in aerodynamics, since it determines: - The amount of lift generated - Any pitching moments - The form drag of an aerofoil section The lift and drag forces of a wing cross-section are dependent on the pressure distribution around the wing. The pressure distribution around an aerofoil is the resultant of the angle of the aerofoil chordline to the oncoming airflow, the angle of attack. If a symmetrical aerofoil section is in a steady airstream at zero degrees Angle of Attack, a stagnation point forms on the leading edge. The airflow velocity above and below the aerofoil increases by an equal amount and the static pressures reduce by an equal amount. Consequently, no pressure differential exists, and no net lift is created. CLMAX AUGMENTATION One of the main factors which determine the CLMAX of an aerofoil section is the camber. Increasing the camber of an aerofoil section increases the CL at a given angle of attack and increases CLMAX. TRAILING EDGE FLAPS Aircraft are fitted with high lift devices to reduce the take-off and landing distances and when low airspeeds are beneficial. This permits operation at greater weights from given runway lengths and enables greater payloads to be carried. Returning the flaps to their neutral position when no longer required, returns the wing to its former aerodynamic characteristics. The increase in lift comes mainly from the variation in effective camber that occurs when the flaps are deflected. This alters the lift curve and also produces a higher maximum coefficient of lift. In some instances, the trailing edge flaps may also increase the wing's surface area. Extending the trailing edgeflaps alters the pressure distribution around the wing. LEADING EDGE DEVICES Leading edge devices increase maximum value of CL and critical angle of attack. But for the constant angle of attack CL is the same or less. (Curve extends to the right and up).

key_points: When an airplane flies at a very low height over the ground (around 50% of the length of the wingspan), the efficiency of its wings is considerably improved
A low wing airplane, just before touchdown, experiences around a 50% reduction of its total drag
This phenomenon is ground effect
learning.explanation: When an airplane flies at a very low height over the ground (around 50% of the length of the wingspan), the efficiency of its wings is considerably improved. A low wing airplane, just before touchdown, experiences around a 50% reduction of its total drag. This phenomenon is ground effect. Ground effect occurs because the surface alters the airflow pattern around the wings. Primarily, the surface restricts the formation of the wingtip vortices. When an aircraft enters ground effect during the landing phase of flight, the sudden increase in lift and reduction in drag cause it to experience a floating tendency. The aircraft also tends to pitch nose-down due to the reduction in download on the tail plane. The magnitude of the wing tip vortices, and thus downwash, also determine the amount of induced drag produced by the wing. The closer the aircraft is to the surface, the greater the reduction in induced drag at any given angle of attack. Aircraft entering ground effect: Downwash decreases. The effective angle of attack increases. Increased lift during landing if the angle of attack remains constant. The induced angle of attack decreases. Induced drag (and induced drag coefficient) decreases. Aircraft leaving ground effect: The effective angle of attack decreases. Decreased lift during take-off if the angle of attack remains constant. Induced drag increases. Downwash increases. The induced angle of attack increases.

content.question: What happens to induced drag when airspeed increases?

options.A: Induced drag increases.
options.B: Induced drag decreases.
options.C: Induced drag remains the same.
options.D: Induced drag is not affected by airspeed.

key_points: INDUCED DRAG Whenever a wing produces lift, concentrated vortices form at the wing tips
The vortices are strongest at the wing tips and become progressively weaker toward the centre-line of the aircraft
It is the production of lift itself which reduces the magnitude of the lift force being generated
learning.explanation: INDUCED DRAG Whenever a wing produces lift, concentrated vortices form at the wing tips. The vortices are strongest at the wing tips and become progressively weaker toward the centre-line of the aircraft. It is the production of lift itself which reduces the magnitude of the lift force being generated. To replace the lift lost by the increased downwash, the aircraft must be flown at a higher angle of attack. This increases drag. This extra drag is called induced drag. The stronger the vortices, the greater the induced drag. INDUCED DRAG vs. AIRSPEED The Effect of Airspeed relates to the changes in induced drag with the variation of airspeed. Induced drag is most significant at low airspeeds and high angles of attack (i.e. during take-off and landing, when it can account for approximately three-quarters of the total drag). To maintain steady level flight, as the airspeed decreases and the angle of attack increases, the slower passage of air rearward over the wing increases the spanwise flow of air around the wing tip. This results in larger wing tip vortices and greater induced drag.

content.question: In straight and level flight, the spanwise flow on an unswept wing is from the...

options.A: lower surface via the trailing edge to the upper wing surface.
options.B: lower surface to the upper surface via the wing tip.
options.C: upper surface via the trailing edge to the lower wing surface.
options.D: upper surface to the lower surface via the wing tip.

key_points: Whenever a wing produces lift, concentrated vortices form at the wing tips
The vortices are strongest at the wing tips and become progressively weaker toward the centerline of the aircraft
The third dimensional flow is the movement of air laterally as it moves to the aft edge of the airfoil
learning.explanation: Whenever a wing produces lift, concentrated vortices form at the wing tips. The vortices are strongest at the wing tips and become progressively weaker toward the centerline of the aircraft. The third dimensional flow is the movement of air laterally as it moves to the aft edge of the airfoil. This is called spanwise flow. As caused by its movement through the air, is that for all positive angles of attack in level flight there is an excess area of low pressure above the upper surface of the airfoil. Thus, air will flow from the relatively high pressure under the lower surface around the wing tip to the lower pressure over the upper surface. Consequently, the flow of air moves outward from the wing root towards the wing tip on the lower surface and from the tip inwards towards the wing root on the upper surface. This is spanwise flow and is a slightly diagonal movement of the rearward airflow. Thus, the airflow over the two surfaces is moving in different directions when they meet at the trailing edge of the airfoil causing vortices to form along its entire length.

options.B: (1) increase; (2) decrease; (3) parasite.
options.C: (1) decrease; (2) decrease; (3) induced.

key_points: Drag is the force which resists the forward motion of the aircraft
Drag acts parallel to and in the same direction as the relative airflow (in the opposite direction to the flight path)
Total Drag is sub-divided into two main types: INDUCED DRAG - the result of lift generation
learning.explanation: Drag is the force which resists the forward motion of the aircraft. Drag acts parallel to and in the same direction as the relative airflow (in the opposite direction to the flight path). Total Drag is sub-divided into two main types: INDUCED DRAG - the result of lift generation. PARASITE DRAG - independent of lift generation. Parasite drag is further sub-divided into: - Skin Friction Drag - Form (Pressure) Drag - Interference Drag The sum of Parasite Drag and Induced Drag is the Total Drag. The Total Drag will be minimum at the IAS where Parasite Drag = Induced Drag. This speed is called Minimum DragSpeed (VMD). Flying at a slower or faster speed than VMD will generate more drag. PARASITE DRAG If an aircraft were flying at zero lift angle of attack, the only drag present would be parasite drag. FORM DRAG Form drag is produced whenever the streamline airflow passing over an aircraft separates from the surface and becomes turbulent. An example of extreme form drag is the effect of a flat plate placed at right angles to the airflow. EFFECT OF CONFIGURATION ON TOTAL DRAG Extension of the landing gear, air brakes, or flaps will increase parasite drag but will not substantially affect induced drag. The effect of increasing parasite drag is to increase total drag at any IAS but to decrease the speed VMD compared to the clean aircraft.

content.question: A crew plan for a full flap landing (30⁰) but, due to distraction, fail to extend flaps from the approach to the landing setting until a few seconds before touchdown. Which of the following statements is correct assuming the correct glidepath was flown to touchdown?

options.A: The aircraft is likely to float and touch down further along the runway.
options.B: There is no problem if the aircraft attitude is not changed.
options.C: There is less risk of a hard landing.
options.D: A go-around is unnecessary.

key_points: Note: There are quite a few factors which affect an aircraft's landing performance and handling
The question and available options do not take into account these different factors
That is to say that the examiner has been very closed minded in writing this question, using a "tunnel vision" approach
learning.explanation: Note: There are quite a few factors which affect an aircraft's landing performance and handling. The question and available options do not take into account these different factors. That is to say that the examiner has been very closed minded in writing this question, using a "tunnel vision" approach. The current correct option is simply the only answer that makes any sense. It is the "most correct" out of a bad bunch, and in itself is arguable, but depending on the circumstances we have not been told, may be true, whereas the other answers are not true in any circumstance. For a given runway length and airplane weight, selecting a greater flap setting will increase the wing’s effective camber and the lift coefficient, which reduces the stalling speed. As a consequence, the take-off speeds are reduced (the same lift will be created at smaller air speed due to greater lift coefficient). This will reduce the take-off run. Flap extension during landings provides several advantages by: producing greater lift and permitting lower landing speed; producing greater drag, permitting a steep descent angle without airspeed increase, therefore Reducing the length of the landing roll. Therefore, the answer here is that using less flaps than expected will cause significantly less drag than expected, so the aircraft may float for a while longer, and therefore have a longer landing roll (that is assuming that the pilot rotates enough during the flare, which has not been specified in the question). As mentioned above, none of the other answers could be correct: There will be a large difference to the handling characteristics, even if the attitude remains the same. There is arguably a higher risk of a hard landing due to the lower "cushioning" effect of the lower flap setting. This one takes longer to explain but most pilots know it naturally from experience. A go-around is very much advised if you realise the flaps are incorrectly set at a low altitude where this cannot be fixed.

learning.explanation: Let's start from the second point. The primary purpose of flaps is to decrease the aircraft's stall speed. This is useful mostly to allow the aircraft to take-off and land in shorter distances, as it can allow the aircraft to fly slower. Secondarily, they are useful for increasing drag, but that is not the purpose of this question. learning.explanation: As we want to remain in straight and level flight, we know for sure that the lift required will remains constant. learning.explanation: STAGNATION POINT In aerodynamics, the stagnation point is the point in a flow field where the local velocity of the fluid (in our case the atmosphere) is zero. content.question: Induced drag may be reduced by:

options.A: the use of a wing tip with a much thinner aerofoil.
options.B: an increase in aspect ratio.
options.C: a decrease of the aspect ratio.
options.D: an increase in wing sweep back.

key_points: Wing tip vortices increase if we increase induced drag
This can be caused by for example increased speed, density or lift coefficient
If we increase Angle of Attack, lift will be increased, also increasing the strength of wing tip vortices
learning.explanation: Wing tip vortices increase if we increase induced drag. This can be caused by for example increased speed, density or lift coefficient. If we increase Angle of Attack, lift will be increased, also increasing the strength of wing tip vortices. Another factor increasing wing tip vortices is the aspect ratio (λ) of the wing. This is the ratio of the wing span to its mean chord. The aspect ratio of the wing is equal to the square of the wingspan divided by the wing surface area. Therefore a short but wide wing has a low aspect ratio but a long, narrow wing has a high aspect ratio. With a lower aspect ratio, the induced drag is higher, thus increasing wing tip vortices. With a high aspect ratio, the induced drag is lower, reducing wing tip vortices. We can therefore state that the relationship between wing tip vortices and aspect ratio is inversely proportional. A wing with a higher aspect ratio has a lower value for CLMAX and will have a higher value of CL for a certain angle of attack.

content.question:
Refer to figure.
Which of the figures shows the change in the total drag graph when density altitude is increased?

options.A: Figure 1.
options.B: Figure 2.
options.C: Figure 3.
options.D: Figure 4.

key_points: When density altitude increases, the air gets "thinner", meaning that there are less air particles per cubic metre, and therefore less air particles will hit our aircraft and flow over its wings per mile flown
This would decrease lift and drag if we were trying to maintain the same TAS
However, to counteract this effect, we fly our aircraft at a constant IAS/CAS (Indicated Airspeed/Calibrated Airspeed), which is a simple measure of dynamic pressure
learning.explanation: When density altitude increases, the air gets "thinner", meaning that there are less air particles per cubic metre, and therefore less air particles will hit our aircraft and flow over its wings per mile flown. This would decrease lift and drag if we were trying to maintain the same TAS. However, to counteract this effect, we fly our aircraft at a constant IAS/CAS (Indicated Airspeed/Calibrated Airspeed), which is a simple measure of dynamic pressure. This value measures the amount of air particles hitting the aircraft, and their speed. If we fly at a constant IAS, but climb higher in the atmosphere, the lower air density means that we have to fly faster to get the same amount of dynamic pressure, meaning the same amount of air particles over the wing, etc. This is an increase in TAS (True Airspeed) for a constant IAS. IAS directly controls our drag and our lift, as they vary proportionally to dynamic pressure, see the lift or drag equation for the mathematical proof here, it is very easy to spot. D = (1/2 x ρ x V2)x CD x S As dynamic pressure is 1/2 x ρ x V2, which is measured by the IAS, then drag is directly proportional to IAS, coefficient of drag, and surface area. If the graph was for total drag against IAS, then the curve would remain in exactly the same position with increased altitude (ignoring compressibility at very high altitudes). As the X-axis on the graphs is TAS, not IAS, then with an increase in altitude, the drag curve will look the same, but will be shifted to the right, due to the increased TAS for the same IAS at higher altitudes, but as the same forces of drag exist at each point on the curve, the curve will not move up or down. The answer is therefore figure 3, moving to the right.

If an actual wing were allowed to stall in this way, stalling would give aileron buffet and perhaps violent wing drop
To give favourable stall characteristics, a tapered wing must be modified using one or more of the following: Geometric twist (washout), a decrease in incidence from root to tip
learning.explanation: In some wing designs, separation tends to occur first in the region of the tip, reducing lift in those areas. If an actual wing were allowed to stall in this way, stalling would give aileron buffet and perhaps violent wing drop. To give favourable stall characteristics, a tapered wing must be modified using one or more of the following: Geometric twist (washout), a decrease in incidence from root to tip. This decreases the angle of attack at the tip, and the root will tend to stall first. The aerofoil section may be varied throughout the span such that sections with greater thickness and camber are located near the tip. The higher CLMAX of such sections delays stall so that the root will tend to stall first.

learning.explanation: Speed brakes are what we call spoilers that are used in flight for the purpose of increasing drag. They are the usual spoilers that are used on the ground to dump lift and some of them are used in the air to aid roll control also. When they are used for speedbrakes in-flight, they do not extend to 90 degrees from the wing, instead only going out to a few degrees to avoid stalling that section of the wing completely. learning.explanation: Coefficient of lift (CL) is a dimensionless coefficient and is the lifting ability of a particular wing. It depends on both the shape of the wing section (fixed design feature) and the angle of attack. This equation is simply a rearrangement of the lift equation where we solve for the lift coefficient in terms of the other variables. The lift coefficient CL is equal to the lift L divided by the quantity: density times half the velocity V squared times the wing area A. key_points: When considering the pressure, we know that the total pressure always remains constant in subsonic airflow
Next, knowing that the total pressure is equal to the dynamic pressure plus the static pressure, we know that if one increases, the other must decrease to maintain a constant total pressure

learning.explanation: When considering the pressure, we know that the total pressure always remains constant in subsonic airflow. Next, knowing that the total pressure is equal to the dynamic pressure plus the static pressure, we know that if one increases, the other must decrease to maintain a constant total pressure. Now what is the dynamic pressure and what is static pressure: Dynamic pressure is equal to: q = ½ rho V2. Therefore we can say that the dynamic pressure is proportional to the velocity of the airflow. Static pressure is the pressure that any object feels even when not moving. This pressure is caused by the force of gravity forcing particles closer together and pushing against each other and any objects around them. Knowing that dynamic pressure is basically the velocity of the airflow, we can say that if the velocity increase, hence increasing the dynamic pressure, there has to be a reduction in static pressure. This is known as Bernoulli’s principle! Going back to the question, we can say that the point of minimum static pressure is the point of maximum dynamic pressure (airflow velocity). Therefore the point of minimum static pressure will be somewhere on the top of a positively cambered aerofoil.

learning.explanation: Flaps are high-lift devices, primarily used to allow flight at slower airspeeds for take-off and landing. Flaps also increase aircraft drag, which can be useful for energy management, particularly on large jets. Flaps increase the camber of the wing, and sometimes extend backwards to increase the wing are too. Increasing the camber leads to an increased coefficient of lift (CL), which allows a higher lift force to be produced from the same airflow. This means that an aircraft can fly slower without stalling, as the same amount of lift required to balance out the aircraft weight will be created at lower indicated air speeds. It is important to note that in level flight, the lift force equals weight, and therefore lift does not change just by extending flaps. All that will change is how slow we can fly and still gain that same lift force (stall speed). We do not use flaps all the time because they also greatly increase the coefficient of drag (CD), so increase the drag force.

Angle of attack (AOA, α - Greek letter alpha) is a term used in aerodynamics to describe the angle between the chord line of an airfoil and the vector representing the relative motion between the airfoil and the air through which it is moving
learning.explanation: Terminology definition angle of attack: angle between the chord line and the relative (undisturbed) air flow. Local airflow = downwash at the trailing edge of the airfoil for example. Angle of attack (AOA, α - Greek letter alpha) is a term used in aerodynamics to describe the angle between the chord line of an airfoil and the vector representing the relative motion between the airfoil and the air through which it is moving. For a two-dimensional airfoil, angle of attack is the angle between the chord line and the direction of arrival of the incoming air. In aviation, angle of attack is used to describe the angle between the chord line of the (three dimensional) wing of a fixed-wing aircraft and the vector representing the relative motion between the aircraft and the atmosphere. Since a wing can have twist, a chord line of the whole wing may not be definable, so an alternate reference line is simply defined. Often, the chord line of the root of the wing is chosen as the reference line. The angle of attack is often confused with the pitch angle of an aircraft and the angle of incidence. Pitch angle and angle of incidence are measured from the same reference line as angle of attack (conceptually the chord line), but pitch refers to the horizon and angle of incidence to the longitudinal axis of the aeroplane. Whereas, the angle of attack is measured from the (same) reference line to the direction of the arrival of the air to the wing (caused by the relative motion between the wing and the atmosphere). Note: Some tricky questions ask about the angle of attack of the aeroplane (not the wing) => angle between speed vector and longitudinal axis.

options.B: The difference in winglet size does not affect the impact of ground effect.
options.C: Aircraft A is LESS affected by the change of induced drag compared to Aircraft B as bigger winglets REDUCE wingtip vortices.

key_points: Note: This appears to be a scenario based version of an older question, number 818975
When an airplane flies at a height equal to or less than the length of its wingspan, the efficiency of its wings is considerably improved
A low wing airplane, just before touchdown, can experience up to a 50% reduction of its total drag
learning.explanation: Note: This appears to be a scenario based version of an older question, number 818975. When an airplane flies at a height equal to or less than the length of its wingspan, the efficiency of its wings is considerably improved. A low wing airplane, just before touchdown, can experience up to a 50% reduction of its total drag. This phenomenon is called ground effect. Ground effect occurs because the surface alters the airflow pattern around the wings. Primarily, the surface restricts the formation of the wingtip vortices and reduces the strength of downwash. When an aircraft enters ground effect during the landing phase of flight, the sudden increase in lift and reduction in drag cause it to experience a floating tendency. The aircraft also tends to pitch nose-down due to the reduction in downforce on the tail plane. The magnitude of the wing tip vortices, and thus downwash, also determines the amount of induced drag produced by the wing. The closer the aircraft is to the surface, the greater the reduction in induced drag at any give angle of attack. Any devices that reduce induced drag will cause ground effect to be less effective, as the induced drag is already lowered. Winglets (or fitting bigger winglets) on an aircraft reduce the size and strength of wingtip vortices, and therefore reduce the induced drag in all stages of flight. Therefore, aircraft A with bigger winglets will not feel as much of a reduction in induced drag during ground effect, therefore the ground effect will be decreased on aircraft A. To put it simply, winglets and ground effect do the same job, and ground effect cannot do as much when (bigger) winglets are already fitted.

content.question:
Which of these statements about induced drag are correct or incorrect?
I. Induced drag increases as angle of attack increases.
II. At constant load factor, induced drag increases with increasing aeroplane mass.

options.A: I is correct, II is incorrect.
options.B: I is incorrect, II is incorrect.
options.C: I is correct, II is correct.
options.D: I is incorrect, II is correct.

key_points: Induced drag is created as a byproduct of lift
The pressure differential between the top and bottom of the wing creates a upwash around the tip of the wing that turns into a downwash behind the wing
This is known as a vortex, which creates a rearward force known as induced drag
learning.explanation: Induced drag is created as a byproduct of lift. The pressure differential between the top and bottom of the wing creates a upwash around the tip of the wing that turns into a downwash behind the wing. This is known as a vortex, which creates a rearward force known as induced drag. This question is asking for the effect of: Angle of attack: The induced drag is proportional to the angle of attack. Therefore, induced drag increases as the angle of attack increases, and, induced drag decreases and the angle of attack decreases. This is because, to maintain lift constant, as the velocity decreases, the coefficient of lift will have to be increased. This is achieve by increasing the angle of attack. At higher coefficients of lift, the pressure differential between the top and bottom of the wing will be greater and therefore produce stronger vortices = stronger induced drag. (and vice versa) Changing mass: Induced drag is proportional to the mass. Therefore, induced drag increases with increasing aeroplane mass, and, induced drag decreases with decreasing aeroplane mass. This is because, as the aircraft get heavier, the lift that the wings will have to produce increases. To achieve that, the coefficient of lift will have to increase, meaning a higher AoA, which creates stronger vortices. (and vice versa) Summary: Higher AR = Lower induced drag Higher AoA = higher induced drag Higher weight = higher AoA = higher induced drag Higher speed = lower AoA = lower induced drag Winglets = lower induced drag.

key_points: Wing tip vortices increase if we increase induced drag
This can be caused by for example increased speed, density or lift coefficient
If we increase Angle of Attack, lift will be increased, also increasing the strength of wing tip vortices
learning.explanation: Wing tip vortices increase if we increase induced drag. This can be caused by for example increased speed, density or lift coefficient. If we increase Angle of Attack, lift will be increased, also increasing the strength of wing tip vortices. Another factor increasing wing tip vortices is the aspect ratio (λ) of the wing. This is the ratio of the wing span to its mean chord. The aspect ratio of the wing is equal to the square of the wingspan divided by the wing surface area. Therefore a short but wide wing has a low aspect ratio but a long, narrow wing has a high aspect ratio. With a lower aspect ratio, the induced drag is higher, thus increasing wing tip vortices. With a high aspect ratio, the induced drag is lower, reducing wing tip vortices. We can therefore state that the relationship between wing tip vortices and aspect ratio is inversely proportional. A wing with a higher aspect ratio has a lower value for CLMAX and will have a higher value of CL for a certain angle of attack.

key_points: Spoilers are aerodynamic surfaces that exist on the top surface of some wings, and are used for many reasons
They are primarily used to increase drag and "dump" lift
(If they are just for drag then they are called speedbrakes, but aircraft manufacturers do blur these distinctions)
learning.explanation: Spoilers are aerodynamic surfaces that exist on the top surface of some wings, and are used for many reasons. They are primarily used to increase drag and "dump" lift. (If they are just for drag then they are called speedbrakes, but aircraft manufacturers do blur these distinctions). They are called spoilers because they "spoil" the airflow, sticking up into the airflow, causing a lift reduction similar to an up-going aileron and a similar drag increase to that of a split flap. Of course, the spoiled airflow is not as effective at producing lift, and the CLMAX of wings with spoilers extended is much lower, so the stall speed therefore increases. The effect on the critical angle of attack is much more complicated, however, and is not always easy to predict. As the spoiler pushes up into the airflow, the adverse pressure gradient over it (which usually causes the stall) is reduced and the airflow is re-energised, but the area behind the spoiler (most do not go all the way to the trailing edge of the wing) is automatically stalled after a small spoiler deflection, due to the gap created. So there are two opposing forces at play: Spoilers act a little bit like an up-going aileron, re-energising the airflow and increasing the critical AoA, The large stalled area behind the spoiler decreases the critical AoA. Therefore, it is difficult to say what effect spoiler deflection will have on the critical AoA. Some sources mention a slight decrease in critical AoA overall, but EASA have published questions like this one where the overall effect is an increase in the critical AoA due to spoiler extension, so we have stuck with this across all questions, as it seems likely that the examiner wants this answer (and feedback has agreed with this in the past). In this case though, the graph given in the question removes all uncertainty, and the only answer is that the graph follows the “B” direction, down and to the right. Of course, the real answer is certain to depend on the proportion of the wing, the size and location of the spoiler, and most importantly, the amount of spoiler deflection. As this is so complex, the examiner’s choice of answer is all that truly matters here.

learning.explanation: Wing tip vortices are a byproduct of lift. They are caused by the pressure differential between the top and bottom of the wing, which causes an updraft of high pressure air around the tip of the wing. This updraft turn into a downdraft behind the wing, creating a vortex. The higher the pressure difference between the top and bottom of the wing, the stronger the vortices. This question is specifically asking for: Angle of attack: The strength of the vortices (and therefore also induced drag) is proportional to the angle of attack. Therefore; the strength of the vortices increase as the angle of attack increases. And also; the strength of the vortices decrease as the angle of attack decreases. Therefore statement 1 is correct! Aspect ratio: The strength of the vortices is inversely proportional with the aspect ratio. Meaning that the strength of the wing tip vortices increase as the aspect ratio decreases. And vice versa: the strength decreases as the aspect ratio increases. Therefore statement 2 is correct!

Speed stability simply means a disturbance to the sped will return back to the equilibrium, whilst speed instability is the opposite. key_points: Note: This question appears to have different answers with different authorities
We think that the question has no correct answer in its current form

Please send us any exam feedback you have about this question so we can get it as representative as possible of the question in the exam quickly, thank you! As far as we currently know, the following authorities are considering the following options to be correct
learning.explanation: Note: This question appears to have different answers with different authorities. We think that the question has no correct answer in its current form. Please send us any exam feedback you have about this question so we can get it as representative as possible of the question in the exam quickly, thank you! As far as we currently know, the following authorities are considering the following options to be correct. Authority Reported Answer Latvia C (maintained its direction.) Poland Not C Austro Not C Spain A (greater than 10°.) Portugal A (greater than 10°.) We would say if your country is "Not C", go for A "greater than 10 degrees". A wing creates a force from the air flowing over it, and the direction and magnitude of that "resultant force" change based on the speed of the airflow, density of the air, and angle of attack (AoA) of the wing. This resultant force is split into two forces we know very well. Lift and Drag. Lift is the component of the resultant force that acts at 90º to the relative airflow (dictated by the speed and direction of the air approaching the wing - not yet affected by the presence of the wing or the aircraft), whereas drag is the force parallel to the relative airflow. This is the basics of "2D airflow", but gets a bit more complicated when we include "3D airflow", the existence of induced drag, wingtip vortices, etc. When flying at higher angles of attack, the effects of wingtip vortices introduce upwash ahead of the wing and downwash behind it, and this changes the "effective" angle of attack, which is the angle of air as it hits the wing, and is approaching from higher up than the relative airflow. The "effective lift vector" is at 90º to this "effective" angle of attack. Because this "effective" lift vector points slightly backwards, some of this "effective lift" is turned into drag. We call that "induced drag". The angle of "tilt" of the effective lift vector is the same angle that our angle of attack changes by (from actual AoA to effective AoA), and this angle of attack that we "lose" is called the induced angle of attack. This is particularly useful knowledge for questions about ground effect. Now to look at this question. When the aircraft slows down and increases its angle of attack to remain straight and level, the actual lift vector (90º to the relative airflow - so directly upwards) must stay the same direction and magnitude, to counteract the weight of the aircraft. The increase in AoA causes an increase in the strength of the wingtip vortices, and therefore the upwash ahead of the wing, thus increasing the induced AoA (the angle of attack that is lost). This means that the "effective lift vector" of the wings tilts back somewhat and increases in magnitude (to keep the actual lift constant), creating more induced drag. This "angle of tilt" (the induced AoA) is much less than the change in total AoA of 10º. Using normal wings, it would be in the region of 3º change. Therefore, the "effective lift vector" would tilt back by around 3º (less than 10º) and increase in magnitude, due to the larger induced AoA. Now that actually doesn't leave us with a correct answer. That is because none of the answers are correct. Even with a question that can be interpreted 2 ways, there is still no correct answer. If you take the question as literally as possible, then the actual lift vector (vertical) does not change in direction or magnitude, remaining vertical and equal to the weight force (option D is therefore wrong due to the magnitude). If you take the question to mean the "effective lift vector", then the correct answer would be "changed direction by a value smaller than 10°, with the lift vector pointing more rearwards because of a larger induced AOA.". None of the other answers fit this. Answer C says that it stays in the same direction with relation to the chord line, meaning that the effective lift vector moves by 10°, the same as the AoA change, which is not correct.

content.question: What type of drag is increased when an aerofoil is contaminated by dust and other particles?

options.A: Material drag
options.B: Induced drag
options.C: Wave drag
options.D: Friction drag

key_points: Total Drag is sub-divided into two main types: Parasite Drag - independent of lift generation, and Induced Drag - the result of lift generation
PARASITE DRAG is simply caused by the aircraft's shape, construction-type, and material
For instance, an airplane with a rough surface creates more parasite drag than one with a smooth surface
learning.explanation: Total Drag is sub-divided into two main types: Parasite Drag - independent of lift generation, and Induced Drag - the result of lift generation. PARASITE DRAG is simply caused by the aircraft's shape, construction-type, and material. For instance, an airplane with a rough surface creates more parasite drag than one with a smooth surface. And there are three basic types of parasite drag: 1. Skin Friction Drag is the result of the aircraft's surface being rough. Olympic swimmers wear swim caps on their heads, so hair doesn't create extra drag and they can swim faster through the water => this same principle can be applied to most aircraft, where a smooth skin reduces skin friction drag, improving performance and fuel efficiency. 2. Form Drag is the result of an object's general shape in relation to the relative wind. Resulting from the pressure at the leading edge of a body being greater than the pressure at the trailing edge. 3. Interference Drag is generated by the mixing of airflow streamlines between airframe components such as the wing and the fuselage or the landing gear strut and the fuselage. As air flows around different aircraft components and mixes, a localized shock wave is formed, creating a drag sum greater than the drag that components would have by themselves. Factors Affecting Parasite Drag: Indicated Airspeed - It varies directly with the square of the Indicated Airspeed. If IAS is doubled, the Parasite Drag will be four times greater - if IAS is halved, the Parasite Drag will be one quarter of its previous value. Configuration - Parasite Drag varies directly in proportion to the frontal area presented to the airflow. If flaps are deployed, the undercarriage lowered, speed brakes selected or roll control spoilers operated, "Parasite Area" is increased and Parasite Drag will increase. Airframe Contamination - Contamination by ice, frost, snow, mud, dust or slush will increase the Parasite Drag Coefficient, and in the case of severe airframe icing, the Parasite Area.

key_points: In aerodynamics, the stagnation point marks the spot in a flow field where the local velocity of the fluid (in our case, the atmosphere) reaches zero
This point typically lies on the leading edge of the wing
When viewed from the side, air above the stagnation point ascends while air below it descends
learning.explanation: In aerodynamics, the stagnation point marks the spot in a flow field where the local velocity of the fluid (in our case, the atmosphere) reaches zero. This point typically lies on the leading edge of the wing. When viewed from the side, air above the stagnation point ascends while air below it descends. Increasing the angle of attack causes the stagnation point to shift downward, leading to more air moving upward over the upper side of the wing and advancing the location of the lowest static pressure point. Consequently, at a specific angle of attack, this airflow triggers the stall warning, emitting an audible alert in the cockpit. The lowest pressure point resides along the upper surface of the wing and shifts in tandem with the Center of Pressure (CP) in response to changes in the Angle of Attack (AoA): an increase in AoA moves the CP forward, while a decrease moves it aft.

learning.explanation: The Lift to Drag ratio (CL/CD) is a measure of how much lift an aircraft produces per unit of drag. So an aircraft with a Lift to Drag ratio of 10/1 is producing 10 times more lift than it is producing drag. The lift to drag ratio depends on the angle of attack. The angle of attack of a clean wing decides its lift coefficient, and its drag coefficient, then you can compare those two to get the lift/drag ratio. In reality, the lift is often much higher than the drag, so the L/D ratio is usually over 1. If an aircraft could fly fast enough to run at a very low (or negative) angle of attack, then its lift produced (which will equal its weight in straight and level flight) could be less than the drag (and therefore thrust - if the aircraft is at a constant speed). It is a bit of a crazy notion for civilian pilots, as the aircraft would have to have a higher thrust than its own weight, but this is quite common in fighter jets, especially modern jets or VTOL jets. We can see that by the fact that they can accelerate vertically upwards.

content.question: Decreasing the aspect ratio of a wing:

options.A: increases induced drag.
options.B: decreases stall speed.
